In equity practice. The showing an item in the debit of an account to be either wholly false or in some part erroneous. 1 Story, Eq. Jur. SS 525. And see Phillips v. Belden, 2 Ed. Ch. 23; Pit v. Choiinondeley, 2 Yes. Sr. 565; Kennedy v. Dickens, 37 S. C. 174, 15 S. E. 922; Tate v. Gardner, 119 Ga. 133, 46 S. E. 73
To disprove; to prove to be false or erroneous; to avoid or defeat; spoken of verdicts, appeals, etc
A high offense against public justice, punishable IP England by 24 25 Vict. c. 98, BSSS 27. 28. and in thetunited States, generally, by statute.
In Scotch law. False making; forgery. "falsing of evil ent is. " 1 Plcc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 85
A forger; a counterfeiter. Hov. 424
Lat. False; fraudulent; erroneous. Deceitful; mistaken
Lat Fame; character; reputation; report of common opinion
A killer of reputation; a slanderer
In Roman law. A house hold; a family, on the composition of the Roman family, see Donati; Coon Ati; and see Mackled. Rom. Law, I 144

In Roman law. An Intermediate person who purchased the aggregate inheritance when sold per ms EI libra, in the process of making a will under the Twelve Tables. This purchaser was merely a man of straw, transmitting the Inheritance to the hares proper. Brown
Persons of the king's household. The ancient title of the "six clerks" of chancery In England. Crabb, Com. Law, 184; 2 Reeve, Eng. Law, 249, 251

A collective body of. persons who live ln one house and under one head or management. Jarbot v. Jarbot, 106 Mo. App. 459, 79 S. W. 1162; Dodge v. Boston A P. It Corp. , 154 Mass. 299. 28 N. E. 243, 13 L. R. A. 318; Tyson v. Reynolds, 52 Iowa, 431, 3 N. W. 469
In the civil and old English law. i Relating to or affecting character or reputation; defamatory; slanderous
Fr. In French marine law. A large lantern, fixed upon the highest part of a vessel's stem
Persons pretending to be Inspired, and being a general name for Quakers, Anabaptists, and all other sectaries, and factious dissenters from the Church of England. (SL 13 Car. U. c. 6.) Jacob
In Spanish law. A measure of land varying ln different provinces, but in the Spanish settlements ln America con-slating of 6, 400 square varas or yards
ER, or FAKIR. A Hindu term for a poor man, mendicant; a religions beggar
In Scotch law. A traveler or merchant stranger. Skene
In old English law. The fourth part of a yardland. Noy says an eighth only, because, according to him, two fardels make a nook, and four nooks a yardland, Wharton
In old English law. A bundle or pack; a fardel. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 22, 10
The fourth part of an acre of land. Spelman
RE. A voyage or passage by water; also the money paid for a passage either by land or by water. Cowell
A mill; a toll of meal or floor. Jacob; Spelman
Money paid by tenants in lieu of a heriot. It was often applied to the best chattel, as distinguished from heriot, the best beast. Cowell
Whoremongers and adulterers

1. The lessee of a farm. It is said that every lessee for life or years, although it be but of a small house and land, is called "farmer. " This word implies no mystery, except it be that of husbandman. Cunningham; Cowell

An unlawful game of cards, ln which all the other players play against the banker or dealer, staking their money upon the order in which the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack, webster; ward v. State, 22 Ala. 19; U. S. v. Smith, 27 Fed. Cas. 1149; Patterson v. State, 12 Tex. App. 224
Lat. An ill-com-posed book containing a collection of mlscel-laneous subjects not properly associated nor scientifically arranged, Wharton
The fourth part of an English penny
The ancient appellation of Serjeants' Inn, Chancery lane
In old English law. A faggot of wood

In Georgia, a "fast" bill of exceptions is one which may be taken ln injunction suits and similar cases, at such time and in such manner, as to bring the case up for review with great expedition. It must be certified within twenty days from the render-tag of the decision. Sewell v. Edmonton, 66 Ga. 353
A day of fasting and penitence, or of mortification by religious abstinence. See 1 Chit Arch. Pr. (12th Ed.) 160, et seq
See Estats
Or FASTING-MEN
In Roman law. Lawful. Dies fasti, lawful days; days on which justice could lawfully be administered by the praetor. See Dies Fasti

The male parent He by whom a child ls begotten. As used in law, this term may (according to the context and the nature of the Instrument) include a pu-tatlve as well as a legal father, also a stepfather, an adoptive father, or a grandfather, but is not as wide as the word "parent, " and cannot be so construed as to include a female. Lind v. Burke, 56 Neb. 785, 77 N. W. 444; Crook v. Webb, 125 Ala. 457, 28 South. 384; Cutheal v. Cutheal, 40 N. Y. 410; Lantznes-Ter v. State, 19 Tex. App. 321; Thornburg v. American Strawboard Co. , 141 Ind. 443, 40 N. E. 1062, 50 Am. St. Rep. 334

A nautical measure of six feet in length. Occasionally used as a superficial measure of land and ln mining, and in that case it means a square fathom or thirty-six square feet. Nahaolelua v. Kaaa-Hu, 9 Hawaii, 60L
A whore. Du Fresne
In old English law. Fa-Tnity; idiocy. Reg. orig. 266
Lat. Fate; a superhuman power; an event or cause of loss, beyond human foresight or means of prevention
One entirely destitute of reason; is qui owning despite. Esk. Inst. 1, 7, 48
An idiot, pr fool. Bract fol 420b
Iu French law, and in Louisiana. A district or part of a town adjoining the principal city; a suburb. See City Council of Lafayette v. Holland, 18 La. 286

(jaws of the land.) Narrow headlands and promontories, inclosing a portion or arm of the sea within them. 1 Kent, Comm. 367, and note; Hale, De Jure Mar. 10; The Harriet, 1 Story, 251, 259, Fed. Cas. No. 6, 099
In the civil law. Negligence; want of care. An improper act or omission, Injurious to another, and transpiring through negligence, rashness, or ignorance
In old English law. A

In old English law. False; counterfeit. Faux action, a false action. Litt. | 688. Faux money, counterfeit money. SL Westm. 1, c. 15. Faux pegs, false weights. Britt c. 20. Faux serement, a false oath. 8t. Westm. 1, c. 38
Bias; partiality; lenity; prejudice. See Challenge
Faithful. Tenants by knight service swore to their lords to be feal and leal
A right ln Scotland, similar to the right of turbary in England, for fuel, etc
Apprehension of harm
A doing; the doing of an act See Malfeasance; Misfeasance; Nonfeasance
Doing, or making, as, in the term "damage feasant, " (doing damage or Injury,) spoken of cattle straying upon another's land
Doer; maker. Feasor del estate, makers of the statute. Dyer, 3b. Also used in the compound term, "tortfeasor, " one who commits or is guilty of a tort

Certain established festivals or holidays In the ecclesiastical calendar. These days were anciently used as the dates of legal Instruments, and ln England the quar-ter-days, for paying rent, are four feast-days. The terms of the courts, in England, before 1875, were fixed to begin on certain days determined with reference to the occurrence of four of the chief feasts

The nearest approach to a system of International law known to the ancient world. It was a branch of Roman Jurisprudence, concerned with embassies, declarations of war, and treaties of peace. It received this name from the fetiales, (q. v. ,) who were charged with its administration
Among the ancient Romans, that order of priests who discharged time duties of ambassadors. Subsequently their duties appear to have related more particularly to the declaring war and peace. Calvin
In constitutional law. A

This is a species of tenure, where land is held of another in perpetuity at a yearly rent, without fealty, homage, or other services than such as are specially corn-prised in the feoffment It corresponds very nearly to the "emphyteusis" of the Roman law
In English law. A

An estate tail; an estate of inheritance given to a man and the heirs of his body, or limited to certain classes of pnr-tlcular heirs. It corresponds to the feud uni talliatum Qf the feudal law, aud the Idea is believed to have been borrowed from the Roman law, where, by way of fidel commissar, lands might be entailed upon children and freedmen and their descendants, with restrictions as to alienation. 1 wash. Real Prop. 66. For the varieties and special characteristics of Thia kind of estate, see Tail
To lend additional support; to strengthen ex post facto. "the interest when it accrues feeds the estoppel. " Christmas v. oliver, 5 Mood. R. 202
In old English law. A thief caught while escaping with the stolen goods ln his possession. Spelman

The name given to certain secret tribunals which flourished in Germany from the end of the twelfth century to the middle of the sixteenth, usurping many of the functions of the governments which were too weak to maintain law and order, and inspiring dread in all who came within their jurisdiction. Enc. Brit. Such a court existed in westphalia (though with greatly diminished powers) until finally suppressed in 1811
Fictitious; pretended; sup-posititlous; simulated

In Saxon law. one bound for another by oath; a sworn brother. A friend bound in the decennary for the good behavior of another, one who took the place of the deceased. Thus, if a person was murdered, the recompense due from the murderer went to the flags of lie slain, IU default of parents or lord. Cunningham
A field; in composition, wild. Blount
L. Fr. Faithful. See Feal
See Sodomy
Companion; one with whom we consort; one joined with another in some legal status or relation; a member of a college or corporate body
A co-helr; partner of the same Inheritance

"the decided weight of authority is to the effect that all who serve the same master, work under the same control, derive authority and compensation from lie same common source, and are engaged ln the same general business, though it may be ln different grades or departments of it, are fellow-servants, who take the risk of each other's negligence. " 2 Whomp. Neg. p. 1026, SS 31. And see Mcandrews v. Burns, 39 N. J Law, 119; Justice v. Pennsylvania Co. , 130 Ind. 321, 30 N. E. 303; wright v. New York Cent. R. Co. , 25 N. Y. 565; Glover v. Kansas City Bolt Co. , 153 Mo. 327, 55 S. W. 88; Brunell v. Southern Pac. Co. , 34 or. 256, 56 Pac. 129; Doughty v. Penobscot Log Driving Co. , 76 Me. 146; Mcmaster v. 111-inois Cent. R. Co. , 65 Miss. 264, 4 South. 59, 7 Am; St. Rep. 653: Daniels v. Union Pac. Ry. Co. 6 Utah, 357, 23 Pac. 762; Weeks v. Charer, 129 Fed. 335, 64 C. C. A, 11
A felon of himself; a suicide or murderer of himself, one who deliberately and intentionally puts an end to
One who has committed felony; one convicted of felony
Felony. The act or offense by which a vassal forfeited his fee. Spellman; Calvin. Per felonies, with a criminal Intention. Co. Litt. 391

Feloniously. Anciently an indispensable word ln indictments for felony, and classed by Lord Coke among those voces arts (words of art) which cannot be expressed by any periphrasis or circumlocution. 4 Coke, 39; Co. Litt 391a; 4 Bl. Comm. 307

Malignant; malicious; done with latent to commit a crime; having the grade or quality of a felony. People v. Moore, 37 Hun (N. Y.) 93; Aidman v. Com. , 18 S. W. 938, 13 Ky. Law Rep. 894; State v. Bush, 47 Kan. 201, 27 Pac. 834, 13 L. R. A. 607; Com. v. Barlow, 4 Mass. 440

With a felonious Intent; with the Intention of committing a crime. An indispensable word ln modern indictments for felony, ns clonic was in the Latin forms. 4 Bl. Coin. 307; State v. Jesse. 19 N. C. 300; State v. Smith, 31 wash. 245, 71 Pac. 767; State v. Harpin, 16 S. D. 170, 91 N. W. 605; People v. Willett, 102 N. Y. 251, 6 N. E. 301; State v. watson, 41 La. Ann. 598, 7 South. 125; State v. Bryan, 112 N. C. 848, 16 S. E. 909

In English law. This term meant originally the state of having forfeited lands and goods to the crown upon conviction for certain offenses, and then, by transition, any offense upon conviction for which such forfeiture followed, ln addition to any other punishment prescribed hy law; as dis

The sex which conceives and gives birth to young. Also a member of such sex. The term is generic, but may have the specific meaning of "woman, " if so indicated by the context. State v. Hemp, 82 Iowa, 609, 48 N. W. 971
L. Fr. A woman. In the phrase "baron et feme" (q. v.) the word has the sense of "wife. "
The killing of a woman. Wharton
In forest law. The fawn-lng of deer; the fawning season. Spelman
Usury; the gain of interest; the practice of increasing money by lending
In Saxon law. A tax or imposition, exacted for the repelling of enemies

A champion, hero, giant This word, in the plural, is generally used to signify invaders or foreign spoilers. The modern meaning of "fenian" is a member of an organization of persons of Irish birth, resident ln the United States, Canada, and elsewhere, having for its aim the overthrow of English rule in Ireland, webster, (supp
The same as feud or fief
Belonging to a FPE or feud; feudal. More commonly used by the old writers than feudal
See Feudal System
Fidelity or fealty. Cowbell. See Fealty

An officer of the court of wards, appointed by the master of that court, under 32 Hen. VIII. c. 20, whose business if was to be present with the escheator in every county at the finding of offices of lands, and to give evidence for the king, as well concerning the value as the tenure; and hia office was also to survey the land of the ward, after the office found, and to rate it. He also assigned the king's widows their dower; and received all the rents, etc. Abolished by 12 Car. II. c. 24. Wharton
In feudal law. The grantee of a feod, feud, or fee; the vassal or tenant who held his estate by feudal service. Termes de la Ley. Blackstone uses "feudatory. " 2 Bl. Comm. 46
In old English law. Fee-Farm, (q. v
The lessee of a fee-farm

This word (meaning a feud or fee) ls the one most commonly used by the older English law-writers, though its equivalent, "feud urn, " Is used generally by the more modern writers and by the feudal law-writers. Litt. 8 1; Spelman. There were various classes of Feola, among which may be enumerated the following; Feodum latent m, a lay fee. Feodum military, a knight's fee. Feodum improprium, an improper or derivative fee. Feodum proprium, a proper and original fee, regulated by the strict rules of feudal succession and tenure. Feodum simplex, a simple or pure fee; fee-simple. Feodum talliatum, a fee-tail. See 2 Bl. Comm. 58, 62; Litt SS 1. 13; Bract fol. 175; Gian. 13, 23
A feoffment. 2 BL Comm. 310
To enfeoff; to bestow a fee. The bestower was called "fcoffator, " and the grantee or feoffee, "feoffat us
In old English law. A feoffer; one who gives or bestows a fee; one who makes a feoffment Bract folk. 12b, 81
In old English law. A feoffee; one to whom a fee ls given, or a feoffment made. Bract folk. 17b, 44b
He to whom a fee is conveyed. Litt SS 1; 2 Bl. Comm. 20

The gift of any corporeal hereditament to another, (2 Bl. Comm. 310) , operating by transmutation of possession, and requiring, as essential to its completion, that the Nelsen be passed, (walk. Conv. 183) , which might he accomplished either by investiture or by livery of seisin
The person making a feoffment, or enfeoffing another in fee. 2 BL Comm. 310; Litt. H 1, 57

This Saxon word meant originally cattle, and thence property or money, and, by a second transition, wages, reward, or, fee. It was probably the original form from which the words "feod, " "feudum, " "fief, " "feu, " and "fee" (all meaning a feudal grant of land) have been derived
In forest law. The fawning season of deer
A certain portion of the produce of the land one by the grantee to the lord according to the terms of the charter. Spell. Feuds, c. 7
Ital. A kind of small vessel or boat. Mentioned ln old Scotch law, and called "frost" Skene
A fardel-land; ten acres; or perhaps a yardland. Cowell
Sax. A summons to serve-in the army. An acquittance from going intothe army. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 47, ( 23
A term denoting, apparently, a freeman of the lowest class, being named after the corseti
In Saxon law. An acquittance of manslaughter committed ln the army; also a fine imposed on persons for net going forth on a military expedition. Cowbell
In old English law. A weekday; a holiday; a day on which process could not be served; a fair; a ferry. Cowell; Du Change; Spelman
Holiday; also weekdays, as distinguished from Sunday. Cowell
In old European law. A wound; a stroke. Spelman
In old records. The fourth part of a penny; also the quarter of a ward in a borough
A fourth part of a yardland
A furlong. Co. Litt 5b
Or FEAR. A house or land, or both, let by lease. Cowell
A farm; a rent; a lease; a house or land, or both, taken by indenture or lease. Plow. 195; Vicar, See Farm

Beverages produced by, or which have undergone, a process of alcoholic fermentation, to which they owe their intoxicating properties, including beer, wine, hard cider, and the like, but not spirituous or distilled, liquors. State v. Lamp, IQ Mo. 391; State v. Biddle, 54 N. H. 383; People v. Foster, 64 Mich. 715, 31 N. W. 596; State v. Gill, 89 Minn. 502, 95 N, W. 449; State v. Adams, 51 N. H. 568
A lessee; a farmer. one who holds a term, whether of lauds or an lucorporeal right, such as customs or revenue
In French law. one who farms any public revenue
In old English law. The winter season for killing deer

In old records. A place ln monasteries, where they received the poor, (aospieio cxcipiebant,) and gave them provisions, (ferm, firma.) Spelman. Hence the modern infirmary, used in the sense of a hospital
In old English law. A waste ground, or place where fern grows. Cowell
In the will law. To be borne; that is on or about the per This was distinguished from portrait, (to., carried,) which signified to be carried on an animal. Dig. 50, 16, 235
The toll or fare paid for the transportation of persons and property across a ferry
In old pleading. An iron mine. Towns. Pl. 273
Iron. In old English law. A, Horseshoe. Ferrara, shoeing of horses

A liberty to have a boat upon a river for the transportation of men, horses, and carriages with their contents, for a reasonable toll. The term ls also used to designate the (place where such liberty ls exercised. See New York v. Strain, 8 N. Y. St. Rep. 655; Broadax v. Baker, 94 N. C. 681, 55 Am, Step. 633; Elnstman v. Black, 14 111
In old English law. Grand holidays, on which choirs wore caps. Jacob

In old English law. A frankpledge, or one who was surety for the good behavior of another. Monasteries enjoyed the privilege of being "free from festlng-men, " which means that they wer "not bound for any man's forthcoming who should transgress the law. " Cowell. See Fbank-Pledqe
Earnest given to servants when hired or retained. The same as arles-penny. Cowell
Lat A
A feast or festival. Cestum stultorum, the feast of fools
Chains or shackles for the feet; irons used to secure the legs of convicts, unruly prisoners, etc. Similar chains securing the wrists are called "handcuffs. "
Fr. In old French and Canadian law. Hearth and home. A term importing actual settlement upon laud by a tenant
In feudal law. An estate in land held of a superior on condition of rendering him services. 2 Bl. Comm 105
Feuds or fees
Pertaining to fends or fees; relating to or growing out of the feudal system or feudal law; haying the quality of a feud, as distinguished from "allodial. "
The feudal system; the aggregate of feudal principles and usages
To reduce to a feudal tenure; to conform to feudalism, webster
A tenant who holds hy feu dal tenure, (also spelled "feodatory" and "feudatory. ") Held by feudal service. Relating to feuds or feudal tenures
A recompense for engaging in a feud, and the damages consequent, it having been the custom in ancient times for all the kindred to engage ln their kinsman's quarrel. Jacob
An occasional early form of "feud" in the sense of private war or vengeance. Termes de la Ley. See Feud
A writer on feuds, as Cuja-Cius, Spelman, etc
In Spanish law. Feud or fee. white, New Rebop. b. 2, tit. 2, c. 2

L. Lat. A feud, fief, or fee. A right of using and enjoying forever the lands of another, which lie lord grants on condition that the tenant shall render fealty, military duty, and other services. Spelman
An abbreviation for fieri facias, (which see
L. Fr. To pledge one's faith. Pelham

Sp. ln Spanish law, trust, confidence, and correlatively a legal duty or obligation arising therefrom. The term is suffl-clentiy broad lu meaning to include both a general obligation and a restricted liability under a single Instrument Martinez v. Runkle. 57 N. J. Law, 111, 30 At. 593. But in a special sense, it designates a surety or guarantor, or the contract or engagement of suretyship
Lu Scotch law. He that has the fee or feu. The proprietor ls termed "fiar, " In contradistinction to the liferenter. 1 Kames, Eq. Pref. one whose property is charged with a liferent
The value of grain ln the different counties of Scotland, fixed year

(lat. "let it be done. ") In English practice. A short order or warrant of a judge or magistrate directing some act to be done; an authority issuing from some competent source for the doing of some legal act
In Roman law. A fiction; an assumption or supposition of the law
An assumption or supposition of law that something which is or may be false is true, or that a state of facts exists
Founded on a fiction; having the character of a faction; false, feigned, or pretended

A term derived from the Latin "fldci-commissartus, " and occasionally used by writers on equity jurisprudence as a substitute for the law French term "cestui que trust, " as being more elegant and euphonious. See Brown v. Brown, 83 Hun, 160, 31 N. Y. Supp. 650

In the civil law this term corresponds nearly to our "cestui que trust. " It designates a person who has the real or beneficial Interest in an estate or fund, the title or administration of which is temporarily confided to another. See Story, Eq. Jur. | 966
In the civil law. A species of trust; being a gift of property

In the civil law. To order a thing upon one's faith; to pledge one's self; to become surety for another. Fide-Jubes? Fide-Jubeo: Do you pledge yourself? I do pledge myself. Inst 3, 16, 1. one of the forms of stipulation

In Roman law. A guarantor; one who becomes responsible for the payment of another's debt, by a stipulation which binds him to discharge it if the principal debtor fails to do so. Mackled. Rom. Law, SS 452; 3 Bl. Comm. 108
See Fidejussor
Lat Fealty, (q. v
See Insurance
Lat To betray faith or fealty. A term used ln feudal and old English law of a feudatory or feudal tenant who does not keep that fealty which he bas sworn to the lord. Leg. Hen. I. c. 53

Lat Faith; honesty; confidence; trust; veracity; honor, occurring in the phrases "bona flies, " (good faith,) "mala flies, " (bad faith,) and "uberrima flies, " (the utmost or most abundant good faith
An adjective having the same meaning as "fiduciary; '' as, in the phrase "public or fiducial office. " Ky. St. SS 3752; Moss v. Rowlett, 112 Ky. 121, 65 S. W. 153
In Roman law. The elder brother of an emancipated pupil-lus, whose father had died leaving him still under fourteen years of age

The term is derived from the Roman law, and means (as a noun) a person holding the character of a trustee, or a character analogous to that of a trustee, in respect to the trust and confidence involved in it and the scrupulous good faith and candor which it requires. Thus, a person Ij a fiduciary who is Invested with rights and powers to be exercised for the benefit of another person. Sane v. Jurgen, 144 111. 507, 33 N. E. 955; Stoll v. King, 8 How. Prec. (N. Y=.) 299
A fee, feod, or feud
In old English law. The holder of a fief or fee; a freeholder on l freeholder
In Spanish law. A sequestrator; a person in whose hands a thing ln dispute is judicially deposited; a receiver. Las Part tides, pt. 3, tit. 9, 1. 1
This term might well be cone; spidered as definite and certain a description as "close, " and might be used in law; but it is not a usual description in legal proceedings. 1 Chit Gen. Pr. 160
An ancient custom in England, by which officers of the forest and bailiffs of hundreds had the right to compel the hundred to furnish them with ale. Tom-Lins

An officer elected, in England, by the owners of a regulated past' true to keep in order the fences, ditches, etc. , ' on the land, to regulate the times during which animals are to be admitted to the pasture, and generally to maintain and manage the pasture subject to the instructions of the owners. (general Iudosure Act, 1845, | 118.) Sweet
In Spanish law. Sequestra, tin. This is allowed in six cases by lie Spanish law w'here the title to property is' in dispute. Las Partitas, pt 3, tit 3, 1. 1
Ancient Gothic courts of an inferior jurisdiction, so called
Lat To be made; to be done. See In Fieri
(that you cause. to be made.) ln practice. A writ of execution commanding the sheriff to levy and make the amount of a Judgment from the goods and chattels of the judgment debtor

(I have caused to he made.) In practice. The name given to the return made by a sheriff or other officer to a writ of fieri facias, where he has collected the whole, or a part, of the sum directed to be levied. 2 Tied, Pr. 1018. The return, os actually made, is expressed by the word "satisfied" indorsed on the writ

In English law. This was originally a tax or tribute, levied at intervals by act of parliament, consisting of one-fifteenth of all the movable property of the subject or personalty in every city, township, and borough. Under Edward III. , the taxable property was assessed, and the value of its fifteenth part (then about PS29, 000) was recorded in the exchequer, whence the tax, levied dn that valuation, continued to be called a "fifteenth, " although, as the wealth of the kingdom increased, the name ceased to be an accurate designation of the proportion of the tax to the value taxed. See 1 Bl. Comm. 309

An encounter, with blows or other personal violence, between two persons. See State v. Gladden, 73 N. C. 155; Carpenter v. People, 31 Colo. 284, 72 Pac. 1072; Coles v. New York Casualty Co. , 87 App. Dlg. 41, 83 N. Y. Supp. 1063

An officer of the superior courts at westminster, whose duty it was to file the writs on Which he made process. There were fourteen filacers, and it was their duty to make out all orlglual process. Cowbell; Blount. The office was abolished in 1837
In old English practice. To file. Towns. Pl. 67
Brit. A name given to villeins ln the laws of Heel Ddn. Barring, obs. St 302
To fix a bastard child on some one, as Its father. To declare whose child it is. 2 W. Bl. 1017
The relation of a child to its parent; correlative to "paternity. "
In old English law. A ferny or bracky ground: a place where fern grows. Co. Litt. 4b; Shep. Touch. 95
In old records. A godson. Spelman
Lat A son; a child
To make full; to complete; to satisfy or fulfill; to possess and perform the duties
A young mare; a female colt An indictment charging the theft of a "filly" is not sustained by proof oi the larceny of a "mare. " Lunsford v. State, J Tex. App. 448, 28 Am. Rep. 414
Lat In old practice. A file; i. e. , a thread or wire on which papers were strung, that being the ancient method \f filing

In French law. An exception or plea founded on law, which, without entering into the merits of the action, shows that the plaintive has no right to bring it, either because the time during which it ought to have been brought has elapsed, which is called "prescription, " or that there has been a compromise, accord and satisfaction, or any other cause which has destroyed the right of action which once subsisted. Poth. Proc. Civile, pt 1, c. 2, 2, art. 2

Definitive; terminating; completed; last. In its use in jurisprudence, this word is generally contrasted with "interlocutory. " Johnson v. New York, 48 Hun, 620, 1 N. Y. Supp. 254; Garrison v. Dougherty, 18 S. C. 488; Rondeau v. Beaumette, '4 Minn. 224 (gil. 163) ; Blanding v. Sayles, 23 R. I. 226, 49 AU 992

A final or conclusive agreement. In the process of "levying a fine, " this was a final agreement entered by the litigating parties upon the record, hy permission of court, nettling the title to the land, and which was binding upon them like any judgment of the court. 1 wash. Real Prop. 70
The public wealth of a state or government, considered either statically
A person employed in the economical management and application of public money; one skilled in the management of financial affairs

To discover; to determine; to ascertain and declare. To announce a conclusion, as the result of judicial investigation, u]on a disputed fact or state of facts; as a Jury are said to "find a will. " To determine a controversy in favor of one of the parties; as a jury "find for the plaintiff. " State v. Buikeley, 61 Conn. 287, 23 At. 186, 14 L. R
One who discovers and takes possession of another's personal property, which was then lost. Kincaid v. Eaton, 98 Mass. 139, 93 Am. Dec. 142

A decision upon a question of fact reached as the result of a judicial examination or Investigation by a court, jury, referee, coroner, etc. williams v. Gibli, 86 wis. 648, 57 N. W. 1111; Rhodes v. United 8tates Bank, 66 Fed. 514, 13 C. 0. A. 612, 34 L. R. A. 742

column1: FINE ANULLANDO LEVATO DE TENEMENTO QUOD FUIT DE ANTIQ-UO DOMUYICO
column2: Ad abolished writ for disannulling a fine levied of lands in ancient demesne to the prejudice of the lord. Reg. orig. 15

column1: FINE NON CAPIENDO PRO PUL-CHRE PLACITANDO
column2: An obsolete writ to inhibit officers of courts to take fines for fair pleading
An absolute necessity or inevitable constraint. Plow. 94; 6 Coke, 11; Cowell
To make or pay a fine. Bract. 106

In old English law. The king's fines. Fines formerly payable to the king for any contempt or offense, as where one committed any trespass, or falsely denied his own deed, or did anything ln contempt of law. Termes de la Ley
In old English law. To fine, or pay a fine. Cowell. To end or bluish a matter
Lat. An end; a fine; a boundary or terminus; a limit Also in L. Lat. , a fine (q. v
An ending; death, as the end of life. Blount; Cowell
Those that purify gold and silver, and part them by fire and water from coarser metals; and therefore, in the statute of 4 Hen. VII. c. 2, they are also called "parters. " Termes de la Ley
Sax. In old English law. A summoning forth to a military expedition, (indiction ad profectionem military.) Spel-Mau
Sax. A preparation to go into the army. Leg. Hen. I
Sax. In old English law. Exemption from military service. Spelman

The effect of combustion. The juridical meaning of the word does not differ from the vernacular. 1 Pars. Mar. Law, 231, et seq
A Scotch measure of capacity, containing two gallons aud a pint. Spelman

A partnership; the group of persons constituting a partnership. The name or title under which the members of a partnership transact business. people v. Strauss, 97 111. App. 55; Boyd v. Thompson, 153 Pa. 82, 25 At. 769, 34 Am. St. Rep. 685; Mc-Cosker v. Banks, 84 Md. 292, 35 At. 935

In old English law. The contract of lease or letting; also the rent (or farm) reserved upon a lease of lands, which was frequently payable ln provisions, but sometimes in money, in which latter case it was called "alba firma, " white rent. A message, with the house and garden belonging thereto. Also provision for the table; a banquet; a tribute towards the entertainment of the king for one night
A Turkish word denoting a decree or grant of privileges, or passport to a traveler
The right of a tenant to his lands and tenements. Cowell
In old records. A place in monasteries, and elsewhere, where the poor were received and supplied with food. Spelman. Hence the word, "infirmary. "
L. Lat. A fervor. A lessee of a term. Firmarii comprehend all such as hold by lease for life or lives or for year, by deed or without deed. 2 Must. 144, 145; 1 wash. Real Prop. 107
The doe season. Also a supplying with food. Cowell
In did English law. Au as surance of some privilege, by deed or charter

A statement lit an affiant "firmly believes" the contents of the attida-vit Imports a strong or high degree of belief, and ls equivalent to saying that he "verily" believes it. Bradley v. Eccles, 1 Browne (pa.) 258; Thompson v. white, 4 Serg. R. (pa.) 137. The operative words in a bond or recognizance, that the obligor is held and "firmly bound, " are equivalent to an acknowledgment of indebtedness and promise to pay. Shattuck v. People, 5 111 477
In old English law. Liberty to scour and repair a milldam, aud carry away the soil, etc. Blount

Initial; leading; chief; preceding all others of the same kind or class in sequence, (numerical or chronological;) entitled to priority or preference above others. Redman v. Railroad Co. , 33 N. J. Eq. 165; Thompson v. Grand Gulf R. B. Co. , 3 How. (miss.) 247, 34 Am. Dec. 81; Hagood v. Brown, 102 Mass. 452
An Anglicized form of the Latin "flies, " (which see
Belonging to the fisc, or public treasury. Relating to accounts or the management of revenue
In Roman la. The treasury of the prince or emperor, as distinguished from "armarium " which was the treasury of the state. Spelman
An animal which inhabits the water, breathes by means of gills, swims by the aid of fins, and is oviparous
A place prepared for catching fish with nets or hooks. This is commonly applied to the place of drawing a seine or net Hart v. Hill, 1 whart. (pa.) 131, 132
A dam or wear in a river for taking fish. Cowell

A term descriptive of a ball in equity which seeks a discovery upon general, loose, and vague allegations. Story, Eq. Pl. 4 325; In re Pacific Ry. Com'N (C. C.) 32 Fed. 263; Hurricane Tel. Co. V. Moler, 61 W. Va. 1, 41 S. E. 421; Carroll v. Carroll, 11 Barb. (N. Y.) 298
In Scotch law. The fiscus or fisc. The revenue of the crown. Generally used of the personal estate of a rebel which has been forfeited to the crown. Bell
In mining law. A vein or lode of mineralized matter filling a preexisting fissure or crack In the earth's crust extending across the strata and gen

Or FESTUCA. In old English law. The rod or wand, by the delivery of which the property in land was formerly transferred in making a feoffment. Called, also, "baculum, " "virga, " and "fustin. " Spellman
In the call law. A pipe for conveying water. Dig. 8, 2, 18

A Norman word, meaning "son. It is used ln law and genealogy; as Fitsher-Bert, the son of Herbert; Fitzjames, the son of James; Fitzroy, the son of the king. It was originally applied to illegitimate children

An act of parliament, passed in 1065, against non-conform-ists, whereby ministers of that body were prohibited from coming within five miles of any corporate town, or place where they had preached or lectured. Brown

1. A fixture ls a personal chattel substantially affixed to the land, hut which may afterwards be lawfully removed therefrom by the party affixing it, or his representative, without the consent of the owner of the freehold. Cook'V. whiting, 16 111 480; Teff v. Hewitt, 1 Ohio St. 511, 59
A place covered with standing water
A national standard on which are certain emblems; an ensign; a banker. It ls carried by soldiers, ships, etc. , and commonly displayed at forts and many other suitable places
Whipped; scourged. An entry on old Scotch records. 1 Pity. Crim. Tr. pt. 1, p. 7
Lat Burning; raging; in actual perpetration
In French law. A crime which is in actual process of perpetration or which has just been committed. Rode d'instr. Crim. art. 41
A case of urgency rendering lawful an otherwise illegal act, as an assault to remove a man from impending danger
A check drawn upon a hanker by a person who has no funds at the banker's and knows that such is the case

A place covered with water too shallow for navigation with vessels ordinarily used for commercial purposes. The space between high and low water mark along the edge of an arm of the sea, bay, tidal river, etc. Thomas v. Hatch, 23 Fed. Cas. 946; Church v. Meeker, 34 Conn. 424; Jones v. Tanney, 8 watts S. (pa.) 443, 42 Am. Dec. 309
In Roman law. The title of a book containing the forms of actions, published by Genius Flavius, A. U. C. 449. Mackled. Rom. Law, { 39. Calvin
A' feathered or fleet arrow. Cowen
A discharge or freedom from amercements where one, having been an outlawed fugitive, cometh to the place of our lord of his own accord. Termes de ia Ley
To leave one's home, residence, or known place of abode, or to conceal one's self therein, with intent, in either case, to avoid detection or punishment for some public offense. Streep v. U

A metaphorical expression, used in connection with hornl-clde done In self-defense, signifying the exhaustion of every possible means of escape, or of averting the assault, before killing the assailant
A place where the tide flows; a creek, or Inlet of water; a company of ships or navy; a prison in London, (so called from a river or ditch formerly ln its vicinity,) now abolished by 5 6 Vict. c. 22
In Saxon and old English law

The possession of the goods of fugitives. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 147
In Saxon law. Land; a house; home
Iu Saxon law. A fine on account of 'brawls aud quarrels. Spelman
In criminal law. The act of one under accusation, who evades the law by voluntarily withdrawing himself. It is presumptive evidence of guilt U. S. v. Candler (D. C.) 65 Fed. 312

In American land law, especially in the western states. A certificate authorizing the entry, by the holder, of a certain quantity of land not yet specifically selected or located. U. S. V. Central Pac

Used for floating. A floatable stream ls a stream used for floating logs, rafts, etc. Gerris v. Brown, 51 Me. 260, 81 Am. Dec. 569; Gaston v. Mace, 33 W. Va. 14, 10 S. E. 60, 5 L. R. A. 392, 25 Am. St. Rep. 848; Parker v. Hastings, 123 N. CL 671, 31 S. E. 833

By this term Is meant that mass of lawful and valid claims against the corporation for the payment of which there is no money in the corporate treasury specifically designed, nor any taxation nor other means of providing money to pay particularly provided. People v. wood. 71 N. Y. 374: City of Huron v. Second ward Sav. Bank. 86 Fed. 276, 30 C. C. A. 38, 49 L. R. A. 534
Floodmark, high-wa-er mark. The mark which the sea, at flowing water. and highest tide, makes on the shore. Blount
A section of a building between horizontal planes. Lowell v. Astrahan, 145 Mass. 1, 12 N. E. 401. 1 Am. St. Rep. 422

A copy of the Pandects discovered. accidentally about the year 1137, at Amalphl, a town in Italy, near Salerno. From Amalphl, the copy found its way to Pisa, and, Pisa having submitted to the Florentines in 1406, the copy was removed in great triumph to Florence. By direction of the magistrates of the town, it was immediately bound ln a superb manner, and deposited in a costly chest. Formerly, these Pandects were shown only by torchlight, in the presence of two magistrates, and two Cistercian monks, with their heads uncovered. They have been successively collated b. v Politian, Bolognini, and Antonius Augustus. An exact copy of them was published in'1553 by Franciscus Taurellus. For its accuracy and beauty, this edition ranks high among the ornaments of the press. Frenchman, who collated the manuscript about 1710, refers it to the sixth century. But. Hor. Jur. 90, 91
A coin originally made at Florence, now of the value of about two English shillings
1. Such things as by accident swim on the top of great rivers or the sea. Cowell

A name for the goods which float upon the sea when cast overboard for the safety of the ship, or when a ship is sunk. Distinguished from "jetsam" and "ligan. " Bract, llb. 2, c. 5; 5 Coke, 106; 1 Bl. Comm. 292
In did English law. Highwater mark; floodmark. 1 And. 88. 89

This term has acquired a definite and specific meaning in late. It commonly imports raising and setting back water on another's land, by a dam placed across a stream or watercourse which is the natural drain and outlet for surplus water on such land. Call v. Middlesex County Com'Rs, 2 Gray (mass.) 235
Flood; floodtide. Bract, fol
In Roman law. A serve tude which consists in the right to conduct the rainwater, collected from the roof and carried off by the gutters, onto the house
Wild fowl; waterfowl. 11 East, 571, note
Lat. A river; a public river; flood; floodtide
In old English law. Flow. Per fluxum et reflux maris, by the flow and reflow of the sea. Dal. pl. 10
On a criminal trial in former times, it was usual after a verdict of not guilty to inquire also, "did he fly for it?" This practice was abolished by the 7 ft 8 Geo. IV. , c. 28, t 5. Wharton

In railroading, a flying switch is made by uncoupling the cars from the engine while ln motion, and throwing the cars onto the side track, by turning the switch, after the engine has passed it upon the main track. Greenleaf v. Illinois Cent. R. Co. , 29 Iowa, 39, 4 Am. Rep. 181; Baker v. Railroad Co. , 122 Mo. 533, 26 S. W. 20
In old English law. A runaway; fugitive; one escaped from justice, or who has no "halford
In did English law. The offense of harboring a fugitive, the penalty attached to which was one of the rights of the crown
Housebote; firebote. Cowell
In old English law. Firewood. The right of taking wood for the fire. Firebote. Cunningham
Food for horses or cattle. In 'feudal law, the term also denoted a prerogative of the prince to be provided with corn, etc. , for his horses by his subjects ln his wars
Provisions to be paid by custom to the royal purveyors. Cowell
See Fodder
A mine. Co. Litt 6a
In international law. A treaty; a league; a compact
Lat In the call law. Interest on money; the lending of money on interest
In medical jurisprudence. Destruction of the foetus; the act by which criminal abortion is produced. 1 Beck, Med. Jur. 288; Guy, Med. Jur. 133
In the civil law. The produce of animals, and the fruit of other property, which are acquired to the owner of such animals and property by virtue of his right. Btfwyer, Mod. Civil Law, c. 14, p. 81
In medical jurisprudence. An unborn child. An infant in ventre sa MRE
In old English law. Foggage or fog; a kind of rank grass of late growth, and not eaten ln summer. Spelman; Cowell
In old English law. The fawning of deer. Spelman
A mark FORFAULT. In old Scotch law. To cried woman; a feme covert.	forfeit 1 How. State Tr. 027
In old Scotch law. Forethought; premeditated. 1 Plcc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 90
Vagabonds. Blount

In Saxon law. A general assembly of the people ln a town or hire. It appears to have had judicial functions of a limited nature, and also to have discharged political offices, such as deliberating upon the affairs of the commonwealth or complaining of misgovernment, and probably possessed considerable powers of local self-government. The name was also given to any sort of a popular assembly. See Spelman; Manhood; Cunningham
In Saxon law. Land of the folk or people. Land belonging to the people or the public
A general assembly of the people, under the Saxons. See Folo-Gbmotb
The common right of all the people. 1 Bl. Comm. 65, 67

In English law. Land to which the sole right of folding the cattle of others is appurtenant. Sometimes it means merely such right of folding. The right of folding on another's land, which is called "common foldage. " Co. Litt. 6a, note 1

A privilege possessed in some place by the lord of a manor, which consists ln the right of having his tenant's sheep to feed on his fields, so as to manure the land. The name of foldage ls also given ln parts of Norfolk to the customary fee paid to the lord for exemption at certain times from this duty. Elton, Com. 45, 46
Menial servants; followers. Bract
In old English law. A freeman, who has no house or dwelling of his own, but is the follower or retanner of another, (heorthfoeat.) for whom he performs certain predial services

1. A leaf. In the ancient lawbooks it was the custom to number the leaves, instead of the pages; hence a folio would include both sides of the leaf, or two pages. The references to these books are made by the number of the folio, the letters "a" and "b" being added to show which of the two pages ls intended; thus "bratton, fol. 100a. "

To conform to, comply with, or be fixed or determined by; as ln the expressions "costs follow the event of the suit, " "the situs of personal property follows that of the owner, " "the offspring follows the mother, " (parts sequitur ventres
Fr. In French law. Goods and effects. Adams v. Akerlund, 168 111. 632, 48 N. E. 454

In French law. A capital ls said to be invested d fond perdus when it ls stipulated that in consideration of the payment of an amount as interest, higher than the normal rate, the lender shall be repaid his capital in this manner. The borrower, after having pale the Interest during the period determined, is free as regards the capital itself. Arg. Fr. Merc. Law, 560
In Spanish law. Any tribute or loan granted to the king for the purpose of enabling him to defray the expenses of a war
A fountain or spring. Bract, fol. 233
1. A measure of length containing twelve inches or one-third of a yard
The fifth part of the conclusion of a fine. It includes the whole matter, reciting the names of the parties, day, year, and place, and before whom it was acknowledged or levied. 2 Bl. Comm. 35L

Iu the forest law. An amercement for not cutting out the ball or cutting off the claws of a dog's feet, (expeditating him.) To be quit of footgeld is to have the privilege of keeping dogs in the forest unlanced without punishment or control. Manhood
In the law of evidence. Impressions made upon earth, snow, or other surface by the feet of persons, or by the shoes, boots, or other covering of the feet. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 264
Hay and straw for horses, particularly in the army. Jacob
Straw when the corn Is threshed out Cowell
One from without; a foreigner; a stranger. Calvin
In forest law. one who could make oath, i. e. , bear witness for another. Cowell; Spelman
In old records. A fore-balk; a balk (that is, an unplow'ed piece of land) lying forward or next the highway. Cowell
A pirate; an outlaw; one banished
L. Fr. To bar out; to
In old English law. The aggressor slain in combat Jacob

The act of abstaining from proceeding against a delinquent debtor; delay ln exacting the enforcement of a right; indulgence granted to a debtor. Reynolds v. ward, 5 wend. (N. Y.) 504; Dierks v. Kennedy, 16 N. J. Eq. 211; Dry Dock Bank v. American Life Ins. , etc. , Co. , 3 N. Y. 354

Power dynamically considered, that is, ln motion or in action; constraining power, compulsion; strength directed to an end. Y.) '667
RE. Fr. In the law of insurance. Superior or irresistible force. Emeric. Tr. des Ass. c. 12

In Louisiana. Those persons whom the testator or donor cannot deprive of the portion of hia estate reserved for them by law, except in cases where he has a just case to disinherit them. Kivu Code La. art. 1495. And see Crain v. Crain, 17 Tex. 90; Haggerty v. Haggerty, 12 Tex. 456; Miller v. Miller, 105 La. 257, 29 South. 802

In practice. A sale made at the time and ln the manner pre scribed by law, in virtue of execution issued on a judgment already rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction; a sale made under the process of the court, and ln the mode prescribed by law. Sampson v. Williamson, 6 Tex. 110, 55 Am. Dec. 762
Preemption; forestalling the market. Jacob
The offense of violently keeping possession of lands and tenements, with menaces, force, and arms, and without the authority of law. 4 Bl. Comm. 148; 4 Steps. Comm. 280

An offense against the public peace, or private wrong, committed by violently taking possession of lands and tenements with menaces, force, and arms, against the will of those entitled to the possession, and without the authority of law. 4 Bl. Comm. 148; 4 Steps. Comm. 280; Code Ga. 1882, | 4524

The action of forcible entry and detainer is a summary proceeding to recover possession of premises forcibly or unlawfully detained. The inquiry in such cases does not involve title, but is confined to the actual and peaceable possession of the plaintiff and the unlawful or forcible ouster or detention hy defendant; the object of the law being to prevent the disturbance of the public peace by the forcible assertion of a private right. Gore v. Alice, 33 wash. 335, 74 Pac. 556; Eveleth v. Gill, 97 Me. 315, 54 At. 757.

In North Carolina, this Is an invasion of the rights of another with respect to his personal property, of the same character, or under the same circumstances, which would constitute a "forcible entry and detainer" of real property at common law. It consists ln taking or seizing the personal property of another by force, violence, or intimidation. State v. Lawson, 123 N. C. 740, 31 S. E. 667, 68 Am. St. Rep. 844; State v. Barefoot, 89 N. C. 567; State v. Ray, 32 N. C. 40; State v. Sowls, 61 N. C. 151; State v. Laney, 87 N
In old records. A ford or shallow, made hy damming or penning up the water. Cowell
A butt or headland, jutting out upon other land. Cowell
In old European law. He who first assaulted another. Spelman
In old records. Grass or herbage growing on the edge or bank of dykes or ditches. Cowell
Sax. Before. Fr. out Eel-Ham
To shut out; to bar. Used of the process of destroying an equity of redemption existing in a mortgagor

A process in chancery by which all further right existing In a mortgagor to redeem the estate is defeated and lost to him, and the estate becomes the absolute property of the mortgagee; being applicable when the mortgagor has forfeited his estate by nonpayment of the money due on the mortgage at the time appointed, but still retains the equity of redemption. 2 wash. Real Prop. 237. Goodman v. white, 26 Conn. 322; Arrington v. Siscom, 34 Cal. 376, 94 Am. Dec. 722; Appeal of Ansonia Nat. Bank, 58 Conn. 257. 18 At. 1030; williams v. wilson, 42 or. 299, 70 Pac. 1031, 95 Am. St. Rep 745
In Scotch law. To for felt; to lose
A premium for a lease
Royal purveyors. 26 Ed. III. c. 5
In English law

Belonging to another nation or country; belonging or attached to another jurisdiction; made, done, or rendered in another state or jurisdiction; subject to another jurisdiction; operating or solvable in another territory; extrinsic; outside; extraordinary

In old English law, this term, when used with reference to a particular city, designated any person who was not an inhabitant of that city. According to later usage, it denotes a person who is not a citizen or subject of the state or country of which mention is made, or any one owing allegiance to a foreign state or sovereign
An old form of foreign, (q. v.) Blount

In old English law and practice. To expel from court for some offense or misconduct, when an officer or attorney of a court was expelled for any offense, or for not appearing to an action by bill filed against him, he was said to be forejudged the court. Cowell
The presiding member of a grand or petit jury, who speaks or answers for the Jury
Belonging to courts of justice
In the civil law. Belonging to or connected with a court; forensic. Forensic homo, an advocate; a pleader of causes; one who practices ln court Calvin
Forsaken; disavowed. 10 Ed. II. c. 1

That part of the laud adjacent to the sea which is alternately covered and left dry by the ordinary flow of the tides; i. e. , by the medium line between the greatest and least range of tide, (spring tides and neap tides.) Sweet

In old English law. A certain territory of wooded ground and fruitful pastures, privileged for wild beasts and fowls of forest, chase, and warren, to rest and abide in the safe protection of the prince for his princely delight and pleasure, having a peculiar court and officers. Man. For. Laws, c. 1, no. 1; Termes de la Ley; 1 Bl. Comm. 289
A duty or tribute payable to the king's foresters. Cowell

To Intercept or obstruct a passenger on the king's highway. Cowell To beset the way of a tenant so as to prevent his coming on the premises. 3 Bl. Comm. 170. To intercept a deer on his way to the forest before he can regain it Cowell
In English law. A
In Scotch law. Murder committed in consequence of a previous design. Esk. last. 4, 4, 50; Bell

In old English law. The taking of provisions from any person in fairs or markets before the royal purveyors were served with necessaries for the sovereign. Cowell. Also the seizing and rescuing of stolen or strayed cattle from the hands of a thief, or of those having illegal possession of them; also the reward fixed for such rescue

To lose au estate, a franchise, or other property belonging to one, by lie act of the law, and ns a consequence of some misfeasance, negligence, or omission. Cassell v. Brothers, 193 Pa. 359, 44 At. 446; State v. De Dress, 72 Tex. 242, 11 S. W. 1029; State v. walbrldge, 119 Mo. 383, 24 S. W. 457. 41 Am. St. Rep. 0i3; State v. Baltimore O. R. Co. , 12 Gill J. (md.) 432, 38 Am. Dec. 319. The further ideas connoted by this term are that it is a deprivation, (that is, against the will of the losing party,) aud that lie property is either transferred to another or resumed by the original grantor
Liable to be forfeited; subject to forfeiture for nonuser, neglect, crime, etc
1. A punishment annexed by law to some illegal act or negligence
UM, or FORGAVE. A

To fabricate, construct, or prepare one thing IU imitation of another thing, with the intention of substituting the false for the genuine, or otherwise deceiving and defrauding by the use of the spurious article. To counterfeit or make falsely. Especially, to make a spurious written instrument with the intention of fraudulently substituting it for another, or of passing it off as genuine; or to fraudulently alter a genuine instrument to another's prejudice; or to sign another person's name to a document, with a deceitful and fraudulent intent. See In re Cross (D. C.) 43 Fed. 520; U. S. v. Watkins, 28 Fed. Cas. 445; Johnson v. State, 9 Tex. App. 251; Longwall v. Day, 1 Mich. N. P. 290; People v. Compton, 123 Cal. 403, 56 Pac. 44. ; People v. Graham, 1 Sheld. (N. Y.) 155; Roar' v. State, 00 N. J. Law, 576, 38 At. 673; Haynes v. State, 15 ohio St. 455; Garner v. State, 5 Lea, 213; State v. Green. Wood, 76 Minn. 211, 78 N. W. 1042. 77 Am. 8t. Rep. 632; State v. Young, 46 N. H. 26, 88 Am. Dec. 212
In original law. The
In old records. A herd-land, headland, or foreland. Cowell
In the call law. Discussions or arguments before a court. 1 Kent, Comm. 530

Lat Foreign; exterior; outside; extraordinary. Servitium fo-rinsecvm, the payment of aid, scutage, and other extraordinary military services. Fo-Rinsecum cancrum, the manor, or that part of it which lies outside the bare or town, and is not included within the liberties of it. Cowell; Blount; Jacob; 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 273

In old English law. Exterior; foreign; extraordinary. In feudal law, the term "forinsec services" comprehended the payment of extraordinary aids or the rendition of extraordinary military services, and in this sense was opposed to "intrinsic services. " 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 273
Lat. Abroad; out of doors; on the outside of a place; without; extrinsic
In old English law. Banished
Lat. To forfeit; to lose an estate or other property on account of some criminal or illegal act. To confiscate
Forfeited. Bona fo-risfacta, forfeited goods. 1 Bl. Comm. 299. A crime. Du Change; Spelman
A crime or offense through which property is forfeited
A criminal, one who has forfeited his life by commission of a capital offense. Spelman

In old English law. Portioned off. A son was said to be forisfamiliated (fortefamiliari) if hie father assigned him part of his land, and gave him seisin thereof, and did this at the request or with the free consent of the son himself, who expressed himself satisfied with such portion, 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 42, 110
In old ' English law. Put Out of a family? portioned off; emancipated; forisfamiliated. Bract, fol. 64
In old English law. Forejudges A forejudgment. A judgment of court whereby a man is put out of possession of a thing. Co. Litt. 100b
Forejudged; sent from court; banished. Deprived of a thing by judgment of court. Bract fol. 250b; Co. Litt. 100b; Du Change
To forswear; to abjure; to abandon

L. Fr. In old English law. to forswear; to abjure
Land ln the diocese of Hereford, which had a peculiar custom attached to it, but which has been long since disused, although the name is retained. But Serv. 56

1. A model or skeleton of an Instrument to'be used in a judicial proceeding, containing the principal necessary matters, the proper technical terms or phrases, and whatever else is necessary to make it formally correct, arranged in proper and methodical order, and capable of being adapted to the circumstances of the specific case
Lat Form; the prescribed form of judicial proceedings
Relating to matters of form; as, "formal defects; " inserted, added, oi joined pro forma. See Pasties
In England, robes worn by the magistrates of a city or corporation, etc. , on solemn occasions. Enc. Lond

The conditions, ln regard to method, order, arrangement, NSE ot technical expressions, performance of specific acts, etc. , which are required by the law In the making of contracts or conveyances, or in the taking of legal proceedings, to insure their validity and regularity. Succession of Seymour, 48 La. Ann. 993, 20 South. 217
In canon law. Canonical letters. Spelman
Formed writs; writs of form. See Brevis Format
An action for which a set form of words is prescribed, which must be strictly adhered to. 10 Mod. 140, 141

In criminal law, and particularly with reference to homicide, this term means a deliberate and fixed intention to kill, whether directed against a particular person or not. Mitchell v. State, 60 Ala. 33; wilson v. State, 128 Ala. 17, 29 South. 569; Ake v. State, 30 Tex. 473

An ancient writ in English law which was available for one who had a right to lands or tenements by virtue of a gift in tall. It was in the nature of a writ of right, and was the highest action that a tenant in tall could have; for he could not have an absolute writ of right, that being confined to such as claimed in fee-simple, and for that reason this writ of formedon was granted to him hy the statute de donis, (westm. 2, 13 Ed. I. c. 1,) and was emphatically called "his" writ of right. The writ was distinguished into three species, viz. : Formedon in the descender, in the remainder, and in the reverter. It was abolished in England by St. 3 4 wm. IV. c. 27. See 3 Bl. Comm. 191; Co. Litt. 316; Fitz. Nat Brev. 255
A certain weight of above 70 lbs. , mentioned in 51 Hen. III. Cowell
ION, or FORMER RECOVERY. An adjudication or recovery ln a former action. See Res Judicata
Lat. Fear of danger. 1 Kent, Comm. 23
In common-law practice, a set form of words used ln Judicial proceedings. In the civil law, an action. Calvin
In Roman law. when the legis actiones were proved to be inconven

Collections of formula, or forms of forensic proceedings and Instruments used among the Franks, and other early continental nations of Europe. Among these the formulary of Marculphus may be mentioned as of considerable interest. But. Co. Litt. note 77, lib. 3
The fee taken by a lord of his tenant, who was hound to bake ln the lord's common oven, (in furo domini,) or for a commission to use his own

Unlawful sexual intercourse between two unmarried persons. Further, if one of the persons be married and the other not, it ls fornication on the part of the latter, though adultery for the former. In some Jurisdictions, however, by statute, It is adultery on the part of both persons if the woman is married, whether the man is married or not. Banks v. State, 96 Ala. 78, 11 South. 404; Hood v. State, 56 Ind. 263, 26 Am. Rep. 21; Com. v. Lafferty, 6 Grat. (va.) 673; People v. Rouse. 2 Much. N. P. 209; State v. Shear, 51 wis. 460. 8 N. W. 287; Buchanan v. State, 55 Ala. 154
Lat A brothel; fornication
In Spanish law. An oven. Las Partitas, pt. 3, tit. 32, 1. 18
In Spanish law. The place where tribunals hear and determine causes, exer-cendarum latium locus
In Spanish law. Emphyteutic rents. Schr. Civil Law, 309
An exception; reservation, ; excepted; reserved. Anciently, a term of frequent use in leases and conveyances. Cowell; Blount
A strip of land lying next to the highway
Waterfalls. Camden, Brit
An attorney or advocate in a cause. Blount; whishaw
In old English law. Prolocutor; paranymphs
See Forestall
In criminal law. To make oath to that which the deponent knows to be untrue

This term means "something ignore than a mere military camp, post, or station. The term implies a fortification, or a place protected from attack by some such means as a moat, wall, or parapet. " U. S. v. Tichnor (C. C.) 12 Fed. 424
A fortress or place of strength, which anciently did not pass without a special grant 11 Hen. VII. c. 18
In old Scotch law. A fortalice; a castle. Properly a house or tower which has a battlement or a ditch or moat about lt

In Scotch law. The action by which an arrestment (garnishment) is made effectual. It is a decree or process by which the creditor ls given the right to demand that the sum arrested be applied for payment of his claim. 2 Kames, Eq. 288, 289;. bell

A bond given to a sheriff who has levied on property, conditioned that the property shall be forthcoming, i. e. , produced, when required, on the giving of such bond, the goods are allowed to remain in the possession of the debtor. Hill v. Manser, 11 Grat (va.) 522; Nichols v. Chittenden, 14 Colo. App. 49, 59 Pac. 954

As soon as, by reasonable exertion, confined to the object, a thing may be done. Thus, when a defendant is ordered to plead forthwith, he must plead within twenty-four hours, when a statute enacts that an act ls to be done "forthwith, " it means that the act is to be done within a reasonable time. 1 Chit. Arch. Pr. (12th Ed.) 164; Dickerman v. Northern Trust Co. , 176 U. S. 181, 20 Sup. Ct. 311, 44 L. Ed. 423. ; Faire v. Manderscheld, 117 Iowa, 724, 90 N. W. 76; Martin v. Pier, 96 Ind. 248

Force. In old English law. Force used by an accessary, to enable the principal to commit a crime, as by binding or holding a person while another killed him, or by along or counseling in any way, or coinmandlng the act to be done. Bract folk. 138, 138b. According to Lord Coke, fortis was a word of art, and properly signified the furnishing of a weapon of force to do the fact, and by force whereof the fact was committed, and he that furnished it was not present when the fact was done. 2 Inst. 182. fortis frisca. Fresh force, (q. c
In old English law. A fortified place; a castle; a bulwark. Cowell; 11 Hen. VII. c. 18

Lat. Stronger. A term applied, ln the late of evidence, to that species of presumption, arising from facts shown ln evidence, which is strong enough to shift the burden of proof to the opposite party. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 64, 66
See A Fobtiohi
Lat Strong. Fortis et sana, strong and sound; staunch and strong; as a vessel. Towns. 11. 227
A place or port of some strength; a little fort, old Nat. Brev. 45
In French law. Accidental; fortuitous. Cos fortuity, a fortuitous event. Fartuitmcnt, accidentally; by chance
Accidental; undesigned; adventitious. Resulting from unavoidable physical causes
Lat. Fortune; also treas-ure-trove. Jacob.
In English law. Persons pretending or professing to tell fortunes, and punishable as rogues and vagabonds or disorderly persons. 4 Bl. Comm. 62
In old English law. A tournament or fighting with spears, and an appeal to fortune therein

In land law's and conveyancing, In those regions where grants, transfers, and deeds are made with reference to lie subdl-vislons of the government survey, this term means forty acres of land in the form of a square, being the tract obtained by quartering a section of land (640 acres) and again quartering one of the quarters. Lent v. Clarke, 22 Fla. 515, 1 South. 149
In old English forest law. The court of attachment IU forests, or woodmote court
Lat. A court of justice, or judicial tribunal; a place of jurisdiction; a place where a remedy ls sought; a place of litigation. 3 Story. 347
In old records. A long slip of ground. Cowell

MERCHANT, or FORWARDER. one who receives and forwards goods, taking upon himself the expenses of transportation, for which he receives a coin-pensation from the owners, having no concern in the vessels or wagons by which they are transported, and no interest in the freight, and not being deemed a common carrier, but a mere warehouseman and agent. Story, Bail. 502, 500. Schloss v. wood, 11 Colo. 287, 17 Pac. 910; Ackley v. Kellogg, 8 Cow. (N. Y.) 224; Place v. Union Exp. Co. , 2 Built. (N. Y.) 19; Bush'V. Miller, 13 Barb. (N. Y.) 488
In the civil law. A ditch; a receptacle of water, made by hand. Dig. 43, 14, 1, 5
In old English saw. The duty levied on the Inhabitants for repairing the moat or ditch round a fortified town
A dyke, ditch, or trench; a place inclosed by a ditch; a moat; a canal
WAY, or FO88E. one of the
A small ditch. Cowell

An ancient custom in Ireland, ln which persons put away their children to fosterers. Fostering was held tobe a stronger alliance than blood, and the foster children participated in the fortunes of their foster fathers. Motley Whitley
ND. Land given, assigned, or allotted to the finding of food or victuals for any person or persons; as in monasteries for the monks, etc. Cowen; Blount
The remuneration fixed for the rearing of a foster child; also the jointure of a wife. Jacob

In Hindu law. Under the Mogul government a magistrate of the police over a large district, who took cognizance of all criminal matters within his jurisdiction, and sometimes was employed as receiver general of the revenues, Wharton

The founding or building of a college or hospital. The incorporation or endowment of a college or hospital ls the foundation; and he who endows it with land or other property is the founder. Dartmouth College v. woodward, 4 wheat. 667, 4 L. Ed. 629; Seagrave'S Appeal, 125 Pa. 362, 17 At. 412; Union Baptist Ass'N v. Lunn, 7 Tex. Civ. App. 249, 26 S. W. 755

Based upon; arising from, growing out of, or resting upon; as in the expressions "founded in fraud, " "founded on a consideration, " "founded on contract, " and the like. See In re Grant Shoe Co. , 130 Fed. 881, 06 C. C. A. 78; State v. Morgan, 40 Conn. 46; Palmer v. Preston, 45 Vt. 158, 12 Am. Rep. 191; Steele v. Hoe, 14 Idol. El. 431; In re Morales (D. C.) 105 Fed. 761
The person who endows an eleemosynary corporation or institution, or supplies the funds for Its establishment. See Foundation
Founderous; out of repair, as a road. Cro. Car. 366
A deserted or exposed infant; a child found without a parent

Fr. In old French saw. An oven or bakehouse. Four banal, an oven, owned by the seignior of the estate, to which the tenants were obliged to bring their bread for baking. Also the proprietary right to maintain such an oven

The face of a written Instrument. That which is contained on the face of a deed (without any aid from the knowledge of the circumstances under which it is made) is said to be within its four corners, because every deed is still supposed to he written on one entire skin, and so to have but four corners

The seas surrounding England. These were divided into the western, including the Scotch aud Irish; the North? ern, or North sea; the Eastern, being the German ocean; the Southern, being the British channel

Fr. To fork. This was a method of delaying an action anciently resorted to by defendants when two of them were Joined in the suit. Instead of appearing together, each would appear in turn and cast an essoin for the other, thus postponing the trial
A form of socialism. See 1 Mill, Pol. Ec. 260

Such fowls as are preserved under the game laws in warrens. According to Manhood, these are partridges and pheasants. According to Coke, they NRE partridges, rails, quails, woodcocks, pheasants, mallards, and herons. Co. Litt. 233
Lat. A breaking; division; fraction; a portion of a thing less than the whole
A breaking, or breaking up; a fragment or broken part; a portion of a thing, less than the whole. Jory v. Palace Dry Goods Co. , 30 or. 196, 46 Pac. 786

As applied to tracts of land, particularly townships, sections, quarter sections, and other divisions according to the government survey, and also mining claims, this term means that the exterior boundary lines are laid down to include the whole of such a division or such a claim, hut that the tract in question does not measure up to the full extent or include the whole acreage, because a portion of it ls cut oft by an overlapping survey, a river or lake, or some other external interference. See Tolies-Ton Club v. State, 141 Ind. 197, 38 N. E. 214; Parke v. Meyer, 28 Ark. 287; Goltermann V. Schiermeyer, 111 Mo. 404, 19 S. W. 487
Arable land. Mon. Angl
Lat. The breaking or wreck of ships; the same as naufragium, (q. v

Lat. Fragments. A name sometimes applied (especially ln citations) to the Digest or Pandects in the Corpus Juris Civilise of Justinian, as being made up of numerous extracts or "fragments" from the writings of various jurists. Mackled. Rom. Law, S 74
Fr. Expense; charges; costs. Frail d'un prods, costs of a suit
A French coin of the value of a little over eighteen cents
In French feudal law. An allod; a free inheritance; or an estate held free of any services except such ad were due to the sovereign
A freeman. Chart

A special privilege conferred by government upon an individual or corporation, and which does not belong to the citizens of the country generally, of common right. It is essential to the character of a franchise that it should be a grant from the sovereign authority, and ln this country no franchise can be held which ls not derived from a law of the state. In England, a franchise is defined to be a royal privilege in the hands of a subject. In this country, it is a privilege of a public nature, which cannot be exercised without a legislative grant. See Bank of Augusta v. Earle, 13 Pet. 595, 10 L. Ed. 274; Dike v. State, 38 Minn. 306, 38 N. W. 95; Chicago Board of Trade v. People, 91 111. 82; Lasher v. People, 183 111. 226, 0 N. E. 663, 47 L. R. A. 802, 75 Am. St. Rep. 103; Southampton v. Jessup, 162 N. Y. 122, 56 N. B. 538; Thompson v. People, 23 wend. (N. Y.) 578; Black River Imp. Co. v. Halfway, 87 wis. 584, 59 N. W. 126; Central Pac
France. Bract fol. 427b
A man born in France. A designation formerly given to aliens in England
L. Lat Free; a freeman; a Frank. Spelman
The privilege of sending certain matter through the public malls without payment of postage, ln pursuance of a personal or official privilege
In old English law. A wood or wood-ground where ash-trees grow. Co. Litt. 4b

In time civil law. A brother. Frater con sanguineous, a brother having the same father, but born of a different mother. Frater u ter inns, a brother born of the same mother, but by a different father. Frater nutricius, a bastard brother
In old records. A fraternity, brotherhood, or society of religious persons, who were mutually bound to pray for the good health aud life, etc. , of their living
Brotherly; relating or belonging to a fraternity or an association of persons formed for mutual aid and benefit, but not for profit
A fraternity or brotherhood

In old English law. "A corporation is an investing of the people of a place with the local government thereof, and therefore their laws shall bind strangers; but a fraternity is some people of a place united together ln respect to a mystery or business into a company, and their laws and ordinances cannot bind strangers. " Cudden v. Eastwick, 1 Salk. 192
Sworn brothers or companions for the defense of their sovereign, or for other purposes. Hoved. 445
In old English law. Certain friars who wore white and black garments, Walsingham, 124
A younger brother's inheritance

Fraud consists of some deceitful practice or willful device, resorted to with intent to deprive another of his right, or in some manner to do him an injury. As distinguished from negligence, it ls always positive, intentional. Maher v. Hibernia Ins. Co. , 67 N. Y. 292; Alexander v. Church, 53 Conn. 561, 4 At. 103; Stumer v. Bleisteln. 115 N. Y. 316, 22 N. E. 243, 7 L. R. A. 702; Moore v. Crawford, 130 U. S. 122, 9 Sup. Ct. 447, 32 L. Ed. 878; Fechbeiiner v. Baum (C. C.) 37 Fed. 167; TO. S. v. Beach (D. C.) 71 Fed. 160; Gardner v. Heart, 3 Denio (N. Y.) 232; Mon
Based on fraud; proceeding from or characterized hy fraud; tainted by fraud; done, made, or effected with a purpose or design to carry out a fraud
See Frank.
L. Pr. A franchise

Lat Fraud. More commonly called, ln the call law, "dolus: ' and "dolus malus, " (q. v.) A distinction, however, was sometime8 made between "fraus" and "dolus; " the former being held to be of the most extensive import Calvin
In old English law. A wood of ashes; a place where ashes grow. Co. Litt. 4b; Shep. Touch. 95
See Affray
In old English law. Freight. Quoad rectum murium sun rum, as to the freight of his vessels. Blount
In old English law. A liberty to hold courts and take up the fines for beating aud wounding. To be free from flues. Cowell
Sanctuaries; seats of peace
A fine paid for obtaining pardon when the peace had been broken. Spelman; Blount. A sum paid the magistrate for protection against the right of revenge
1. Unconstrained; having power to follow the dictates of his own will. Not subject to the dominion of another. Not compelled to involuntary servitude. Used in this sense as opposed to "slave. "
A sale of goods "free on board" Imports that they are. to be delivered on board the cars, vessels, etc. , without expense to the buyer for packing, cartage, or other such charges

In Roman law. one who was set free from a state of bondage; an emancipated slave. The word Is used in the same sense In the United States, respecting negroes who were formerly slaves. Fairfield v. Lawson, 50 Conn. 513, 47 Am. Rep. 669; Davenport v. Caldwell, 10 S. C. 333
The state of being free; liberty; self-determination; absence of restraint; the opposite of slavery

An estate in land or other real property, of uncertain duration; that is, either of inheritance or which may possibly last for the life of the tenant at the least, (as distinguished from a leasehold;) and held by a free tenure, (as distinguished from copyhold or villeinage.) Neavitt v. Woodburn, 175 111. 376, 51 N. E. 593; Railroad Co. v. Hemphill, 35 Miss. 22; Nellis v. Munson, 108 N. Y. 453, 15 N. E. 739; Jones v. Jones, 20 Ga. 700

This word has had various meanings at different stages of history. In the Roman law, it denoted one who was either bom free or emancipated, and was the opposite of "slave. " In feudal law, It designated an allodial proprietor, as distinguished from a vassal or feudal tenant (and so in Pennsylvania colonial law. Fry'S Election Case, 71 Pa. 308, 10 Am. Rep. 698.) ln old English law, the word described a freeholder or tenant by free services; one who was not a villein. In modern legal phraseology, it ls the appellation of a member of a city or borough having the right of suffrage, or a member of any municipal corporation invested with full civic rights

Freight Is properly the price or compensation paid for the transportation of goods by a carrier, at sea, from port to port. But the term is also used to denote the hire paid for the carriage of goods on laud from place to place, (usually by a railroad company, not au express company,)

In maritime law. The party by whom a vessel is engaged or chartered; otherwise called the "charterer. " 2 Steps. Comm. 148. In French law, lie owner of a vessel Is called the "freighter, " (fretful;) the merchant who hires It ls called the "affreighter, " (fretful.) Emeric. Tr. des Ass. ch. 11. 3
In early times, ln English law, this term was applied to every stranger or "outlandish" man. Bruit lib. 3, tr. 2, c. 15
Sax. An outlaw. So called because on his outlawry he was denied all help of friends after certain days. Cowbell; Blount
Ln old English law. A mulct or fine exacted from him who harbored au outlawed friend. Cowell; Tomkins
In old English law. A madman, or person in a frenzy. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 36
A free-surety, or freepledge. Spelman. See Frankpledge
Fr. A brother. Frere gene, elder brother. Frere puisne, younger brother. Britt c. 75
In old records. Fresh water, or rain and land flood
Immediate; recent; following without any material interval
ET. A flood, or overflowing of a river, by means of rains or melted snow; an inundation. Stover v. Insurance Co. , 3 Phila. (i'a.) 42; Harris v. Social Mfg. Co. , 9 R. I. 99. 11 Am. Rep. 224
Fr. In French marine law. Freight, ord. Mar. Liv. 3, tit. 3
Fr. In French marine law. To freight a ship; to let It. fcmerig. Tr. des Ass. c. 11, | 3
Fr. In French marine law. Freighter. The owner of a ship, who lets it to the merchant Emeric. Tr. des Ass. c. 11, 13
In old English law. The freight of a ship; freight money. Cowell
Lat A strait

An order of religious persons, of whom there were four principal branches, viz. : (1) Minors, Grey Friars, or Franciscans; (2) Augnstines; (3) Dominicans, or Black Friars; (4) white Friars, or Carmel-Ltes, from whom the rest descend, Wharton

In the Kivu law. A temporary separation between husband and wife, caused by a quarrel or estrangement, but not amounting to a divorce, because not accompanied with an Intention to dissolve the marriage
Frankpledge. Cowell Security for the peace. Spelman
Ln old English law. A kind of frankpledge, by w'hich the lords or principal men were made responsible for their dependents or servants. Bract, fol. 124b
See Amicus Curls
In old English law. An outlaw; so called because he was deuced all help of friends. Bract lib. 3, tr. 2, c. 12

In English law. Associations supported by subscription, for the relief and maintenance of the members, or their wives, children, relatives, and nominees, in sickness, infancy, advanced age, widowhood, etc. The statutes regulating these societies were consolidated and amended by St. 38 39 Lct. c. 60. Wharton

A suit brought by a creditor in chancery against an executor or administrator, being really a suit hy the executor or administrator, in the name of a creditor, against himself, in order to compel the creditors to take an equal distribution of the assets. 2 Williams, Ex'Rs, 1915
Impotence. Johnson
Persons of free descent, or freemen born; the middle class of persons among the Saxons. Spelman
Fresh uncultivated ground. Mon. Angl. t. 2, p. 56. Fresh; not salt. Reg. orig. 97. Recent or new. See Best, and subtitles thereunder
Sax. Peace, security, or protection. This word occurs in many compound terms used in Anglo-Saxon law

An answer or plea is called "frivolous" when it is clearly insufficient on its face, and does not controvert the material points of the opposite pleading, and is presumably interposed for mere purposes of delay or to embarrass the plaintiff. Erwin v. Lowery, 64 N. C. 321; Strong v. Sproul, 53 N. V. 499; Gray v. Gidiere, 4 Scrob. (S. C.) 442; Peacock v. williams (C. C.) 110 Fed. 916
Or FREOMORTEL

FRONTAGER. ln English law a frontager Is a person owning or occupying land which abuts on a highway, river, seashore, or the like. The term ls generally used with reference to the liability of frontagers on streets to contribute towards the expense of paving, draining, or other works on the highway carried out by a local authority, in proportion to the frontage of their respective tenements. Sweet
In International law. That portion of the territory of any country which lies close along the border line of another country, and so "fronts" or faces it
In the civil law. Anything produced from vines, underwood, chalkpits, stone-quarries. Dig. 50, 16, 77
The produce of a tree or plant which contains the seed or is used for food
