In the civil law. Grain. That which grows ln an ear. Dig. 50, 16, 77
Sax. The first payment made to the kindred of a slain person in recompense for his murder. Blount
A breaking; plowing. Cowell
A piece or parcel of land lying by Itself. Co. Litt. 5b
In old records. A place overgrown with shrubs and; bushes. Spellman; Blount
In Spanish law. Fruits; products; produce; grains; profits, white. New Rebop. h. 1, tit. 7, c. 5. SS 2
In old English law. The affording harbor and entertainment # to any one
Sax. In old English law. A plain between woods. Co. Litt. 5b
Hearth money. A tax laid upon each fireplace or hearth. An imposition of a shilling for every hearth, levied by Edward III. in the dukedom of Aquitaine. Spelman; 1 Bl. Comm. 324
In old English law. Flight. It is of two kinds: (1) Fur in fit. or in facto, where a person does apparently and corporally flee; (2) fur in leg. or in lege
In Spanish law. A law; a code
In old English law. A drove of cattle. Blount
A chase. Blount

Lat. He has made flight; he fled. A clause inserted in an ln-qulsltion, in old English law', meaning that a person indicted for treason or felony had fled. The effect of this is to make the party forfeit his goods absolutely, aud the profits of his lands until he has been pardoned or acquitted
In old English law. A privilege to hunt. Blount
In Scotch practice. To outlaw, by the sentence of a court; to outlaw for nonappearance in a criminal case. 2 Alls. Crim. Pr. 350
One who flees; always used ln law with the implication of a flight, evd-sion, or escape from some duty or penalty or from the consequences of a misdeed
In the civil law. A fugitive: a runaway slave. Dig. 11, 4; Cod. 6
Fr. In medical jurisprudence. Ambulatory automatism. See Automatism
Ample; complete; perfect: mature; not wanting in any essential quality. Mobile School Com'Rs v. Putnam, 44 Ala. 537; Reed v. Hazleton, 37 Kan. 321, 15 Pac. 177; Quinn v. Donovan, 85 111. 195
A fleam, or stream of water. Blount

The English equivalent of the Latin phrase "plane admin-istravit; " being a plea by in executor or administrator that he has completely and legally disposed of ail the assets of the estate, and has nothing left out of which a new claim could be satisfied. See Roans v. Booger, 169 Mo. 673, 69 S. W. 1048
In old English saw. The same as fuage, or smoke farthings. 1 Bl. Comm. 324. See Fuage

Office; duty; fulfillment of a definite end or set of ends by the correct adjustment of means. The occupation of an office. By the performance of its duties, the officer is said to fill his function. Dig. 32, 65, 1. See State v. Hyde, 121 Ind. 20, 22 N. E. 644

In medical jurisprudence, one which prevents, obstructs, or interferes with the due perforin-ance of its special functions by any organ of the body, without anatomical defect or abnormality in the organ itself. See Higbee v. Guardian Mut. L. Ins. Co. , 66 Barb. (N. Y.) 472. Distinguished from "organic" disease, which is due to some injury to, or lesion or malformation in, the organ in question
A public officer or employs. An officer of a private corporation is also sometimes so called

Lat. Having fulfilled the function, discharged the office, or accomplished the purpose, and therefore of no further force or authority. Applied to an officer whose term has expired, and who has consequently no further official authority; and also to an instrument, power, agency, etc. , which has fulfilled the purpose of Its creation, and is therefore of no further virtue or effect
See Elbow
The law which determines the constitution of government in a state, and prescribes and regulates the manner of its exercise; the organic law of a state; the constitution
We found. ' one of the words by which a corporation may be created ln England. 1 Bl. Comm. 473; 3 Steps. Comm. 173

Lat. A founding or foundation. Particularly applied to the creation and endowment of corporations. As applied to eleemosynary corporations such as colleges and hospitals, it is said that "foundation incipient" is the incorporation or grant of corporate powers, while "foundation perflciens" is the endowment or grant or gift of funds or revenues. Dartmouth College v. Woodward, 4 wheat. 667, 4 L. Ed. 629
A founder, (q. v
Lands of inheritance
Pioneers. Jacob
In the civil and old English law. Land; land or ground generally; land
Money expended in procuring the interment of a corpse
Movable goods which may be estimated and replaced according to weight, measure, and number. Things belonging to a class, which do not have to be dealt with in specie
Lat. In the civil law. Fungible things. See that title
Lat. An intention of stealing
In old English law. A fork. A gallows or gibbet. Bract, fol. 56
A fine or mulct paid for theft
In Scotch law. Madness, as distinguished from fatuity or Idiocy
Lat. Au insane man; a madman; a lunatic
A furlong, or a furrow one-eighth part of a mile long. Co. Litt 5b
A measure of length, being forty poles, or one-eighth of a mile
Leave of absence; especially, leave given to a military or naval of finer, or soldier or seaman, to be absent from service for a certain time. Also the document granting leave of absence
See Fobnaoium; Four

To supply; provide; provide for use. Delp v. Brewing Co. , 123 Pa. 42, 15 At. 871; Wyatt v. Larimer W. Err. Co. , 1 Colo. App. 480, 29 Pac. 906. As used in the liquor laws, "furnish" means to provide In any way, and includes giving as well as selling. State v. Freeman, 27 Vt. 520; State v. Vague, 76 Vt. 118, 56 At. 535

This term includes that which furnishes, or with which anything is furnished or supplied; whatever must be supplied to a house, a room, or the like, to make it habitable, convenient, or agreeable; goods, vessels, utensils, and other appendages necessary or convenient for housekeeping; whatever Is added to the interior of a house or apartment, for use or convenience. Bell v. Golding, 27 Ind. 173
In old English law. Time to advise or take counsel, Jacob

In most of Its uses ln law, this term means additional, though occas-sionully it may mean any, future, or other. See London S. F. Bank v. Parrott, 125 Cal. 472, 58 Pac. 164, 73 Am. St. Rep. 64; Hutchings v. Van Brunt, 38 N. Y. 338; Fifty Associates v. Howland, 5 Cush. (mass.) 218; o'fallon v. Nicholson, 56 Mo. 238; Pennsylvania Co. v. Loughlin, 139 Pa. 612, 21 At. 163
In old English law. Stealthily; by stealth. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 38, SS 3
In old English law. A heating with sticks or clubs; one of the ancient kinds of punishment of malefactors. Bract fol. 104b, lib. 3, tr. 1, c. 6
In old English law. A staff, used in making livery of seisin. Bract, fol. 40
In Scotch law. A debt which is created, but which will not become due till a future day. 1 Bell, Comm
See Estate
This term has grown out of those purely speculative transactions, in which there ls a nominal contract of sale for

Lat. Those who are to be. Part of the commencement of old deeds. "scant presented et future, quod ego talis, ded et conessi, " etc. , (let all men now living and to come know that I, A. B. , have, etc.) Bract, fol. 34b
Or FUST. A Celtic word, meaning a wood or forest
One of the fines incurred for homicide
A bonnet for catching fish. Pub. St Mass. 1882, p. 1291
In old Scotch law. To defile; to declare foul or defiled. Hence, to find a prisoner guilty
In old Scotch practice. Fyled; found guilty. See Eruc
PSAP. In Anglo-Saxon law. The military array or land force of the whole country. Contribution to the fyrd was one of the imposts forming the trinode necessity. (also spelled "ferd" and "fled. "
An excise; a tax on movables; a rent, custom, or service. Co. Litt. 213. land Gabel. See Land
The Law Latin form of "gabel, " (q. v
Persons who paid Gabel, rent, or tribute. Domesday; Cowell
A rent; a tax. Domesday; Du Change. The gable-end of a house. Cowbell
Rent paid ln money. Seld. Txt. Hon. 321
The payment of custom or tribute. Scott
Property subject to the gaffoldgild, or liable to be taxed. Scott
The same word as "gabel" or "gavel. " Rent; tax; interest of money
Wager of law, (q. v
Profits; winnings; Increment of value, Gray v. Darlington, 15 wall. 65, 21

The gain or profit of tilled or planted land, raised by cultivating it; and the draught, plow, and furniture for carrying on the work of tillage by the baser kind of sokemen or villeins. Bract. 1. 1. c. 9
Tillage, or the profit arising from it, or from the beasts employed therein
In old English law. A sokeman; one who occupied or cultivated arable land, old Nat. Brev. fol. 12
A thick wood. Spelman
The payment of a rent, tax, duty, or annuity
In old records. A piratical vessel; a galley
In old Scotch law. Amends or compensation for slaughter. Bell
A kind of coin which, with susklns and doitkins, was forbidden by St. 3 Hen. V. c. 1

A liquid measure, containing 231 cubic Inches, or four quirts. The imperial gallon contains about 277, and the ale gallon 282, cubic inches. Hollander v. Ma-Gone (C. C.) 38 Fed. 914; Nichols v. Beard (C. C.) 15 Fed. 437
A scaffold; a beam laid over either one or two posts, from which malefactors are hanged
In old European law. A stroke or blow. Spelman
A child born ln lawful wedlock; also one born to betrothed but unmarried parents. Spelman
To game or play at a game for money. Buckley v. o'niel, 113 Mass. 193. 38 Am. Rep. 460. The word "gamble" ls perhaps the most apt and substantial to convey

1. Birds and beasts of a wild nature, obtained by fowling and hunting. Bacon, Abr. See Coolidge v. Choate, 11 Met. (mass.) 79. The term is said to include (in England) hares, pheasants, partridges, grosse, heath or moor game, black game, and bustards. Brown. See 1 2 wm. IV. c. 32

The act or practice of play ing games for stakes or wagers; gambling; the playing at any game of hazard. An agreement between two 6r more persons to play together at a game of chance for a stake or wager which is to become the property of the winner, and to which all contribute. In re Stewart (D. C.) 21 Fed. 398; People v. Todd, 51 Hun, 446, 4 N. Y. Supp. 25; State v. Shaw, 39 Minn. 153, 39 N. W. 305; State v. Morgan, 133 N. C. 743, 45 S. E. 1033
In Spanish
In Spanish law. Gains or profits resulting from the employment of property held by husband and wife in common. white, New Rebop. b. 1, txt 7, c. 5
The time when the bounds of the parish are lustrated or gone over by the parish officers, rogation week. Enc. Lond
Officers in ancient times whose business it was to examine weights and measures. Skene
A prison for temporary confinement; a jail; a place for the confinement of offenders against the law
In criminal law. The delivery or clearing of a gaol of the prisoners confined therein, by trying them
Or GRANTIA. A warranty. Spelman

In French law. This word corresponds to warranty or covenants for title in English law. In the case of a sale this guarantee extends to two things: (1) Peaceful possession of the thing sold; and (2) absence of undisclosed defects, (difauts caches.) Brown
In old Lombardic law. A gift; a free or absolute gift; a gift of the whole of a thing. Spelman

L. Fr. In old English law. A warrantor of land; a vouchee; one bound by a warranty to defend the title and seisin of his alienee, or, on default thereof, and on eviction of the tenant, to give him other lands of equal value. Britt, c. 75
In old English law. A bundle or sheaf. Blade in gorbit, corn or grain in sheaves. Reg. orig. 96; Bract, fol. 209
In Scotch law. Tythes of corn, (grain.) Bell
In English statutes. To sort or cull out the good from the bad in spices, drugs, etc. Cowell
Servants who follow a camp. was. 242
Or GARDE. L. Fr. wardship; care; custody; also the ward of a city
A keeper; a guardian
A small piece of land, appropriated to the cultivation of herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables. People v. Greeuburgh. 57 N. Y. 550; Ferry v. Livingston, 115 U. S. 542, 6 Sup. Ct. 175, 29 L. Ed. 489
L. Fr. Custody; wardship
In old English law. A guardian, defender, or protector. In feudal law, Gardia. Spelman
In old English law. A garden. Reg. orig. lb, 2
L. Fr. A warren; a privileged place for keeping animals
In old English law. Victuals, arms, and other Implements of war, necessary for the defense of a town or castle. Mat. Par. 1250

In the process of attachment. A warning to a person ln whose hands the effects of another are attached not to pay the money or deliver the property of the defendant ln his hands to him, but to appear and answer the plalntlfts salt. Drake. Attaching. S 451; National Bank of wllmlng-ton v. Furtive. 2 Marv. (del.) 35, 42 At. 479, 44 L. R. A. 115, 69 Am. St. Rep. 99; Georgia A. Ry. Co. v. Stollenwerck, 122 Ala. 539, 25 South. 258; Weary v. American Exch. Bank, 2 Neb. (UNEF.) G57. 89 N. W. 772
In old English law. Garniture; whatever is necessary for the fortification of a city or camp, or for the ornament of a thing. 8 Remer, 328; Du Change; Cowell; Blount

A method of inflicting the death penalty on convicted criminals practised in Spain, Portugal, aud some Spauish-American countries, consisting in strangulation by means of an iron collar which is mechanically tightened about the neck of the sufferer, sometimes with the variation that a sharpened screw is made to advance from the back of the apparatus and pierce the base of the brain. Also, popularly, any form of strangling resorted to to overcome resistance or induce unconsciousness, especially as a concomitant to highway robbery
In old English law. An amerciament or fine. Cowell

A string or ribbon by which lie stocking is held upon the leg. The mark of the highest order of English knighthood, ranking next after the nobility. This military order of knighthood is said to have been first instituted by Richard I. , at the siege of Acre, where he caused twenty-six knights who firmly stood by him to wear thongs of blue leather about their legs. It is also said to have been perfected by Edward III. and to have received some alterations, which were
In old Scotch law. warder. 1 Plcc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 8
A temporary governor of the country. Blount. A bailiff or steward. Spelman
L. Fr. wastel; wastel bread; the finest sort of wheat bread. Britt c. 30 i rfelham
L. Fr. waste or uncultivated ground. Britt. c. 57
A term used in the English universities to denote double commons
The measure of width of a railway, fixed, with some exceptions, at 4 feet 8 Inches in Great Britain and America, and 5 feet 3 inches in Ireland
A gauger. Lowell

A surveying officer under the customs, excise, and internal revenue laws, appointed to examine all tuns, pipes, bogs-heads, barrels and tierces of wine, oil, and other liquids, aud to give them a mark of allowance, as containing lawful measure. There are also private gaugers In large seaport towns, who are licensed by government to perform the same duties. Papal. L
A gauge or gauging; a measure of the contents of any vessel

Ln English law. Custom; tribute; toll; yearly rent; payment of revenue; of which there were anciently several sorts; as gavel-corn, gavel-malt, oat-garcl, garel-fodder, etc. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Co. Litt. 142a

An ancient and special kind of cessavit, used in Kent and London for the recovery of rent, obsolete. The statute of gavelet is 10 Ed. II. 2 Reeve, Eng. I4Tw, c. 12, p. 298. See Emit v. Cunningham, 62 Md. 460

A species of socage tenure common ln Kent, In England, where the lands descend to all the sons, or heirs of the nearest degree, together; may be disposed of by will; do not escheat for felony; may be aliened by the heir at the age of fifteen; and dower and curtesy is given of half the land. Stim. Law Gloss

An officer of the English crown having the general management of the mines, pits, and quarries ln the Forest of Dean and Hundred of St. Brlavel'S, subject, ln some respects, to the control of the commissioners of woods and forests. Ile grants gales to free miners in their proper order, accepts surrenders of gales, and keeps the registers required by the acts. There is a deputy-gaveller, who appears to exercise most of the gaveller's functions. Sweet

The official publication of the English government, also called the "london Gazette. " It ls evidence of acts of state, and of everything done by the king ln his political capacity, orders of adjudica-tlon in bankruptcy are required to be pttb-llshed therein; and the production of a copy of the "gazette, " containing a copy of lie order of adjudication, is evidence of the fact Motley Whitley
An Anglo-Saxon term, meaning "conveyed. "
In Saxon law. To convey; to transfer boc land, (bookland or land held by charter.) The grantor was said to gebo-cjan the alienee. See 1 Reeve. Eng. Law, 10
In old English law. Neighborhood or adjoining district. Cowell
In old English law. A country neighbor; an inhabitant of the same geb-urscript, or village. Cowell

In Saxon law. Money or tribute. A mulct, compensation, value, price. Angel was the single value of a thing; twirled, doable value, etc. So, heregeld was the value of a man slain; orfgild, that of a beast Brown.
In old English law. Taxiable; geldable
Liable to pay geld; liable to be taxed. Pelham
A horse that has been castrated, and which is thus distinguished from the horse ln his natural and unaltered con
Lat. In the civil law. A gem; a precious stone. Gems were distinguished by their transparency; such as ein-eralds, chrysolites, amethysts. Dig. 34, 2, 19, 17

In Saxon law. A meeting or moot; a convention; a public assemblage. These were of several sorts, such, as the witenagemot, or meeting of the wise men; the folcgemot, or general assembly of the people; the shire-gemot, or county court; the burg-gemot, or borough court; the hundred-gemot, or hundred court; the hali-gemot, or court-baron; the halimote, a convention of citizens in their public hall; the holy-mote, or holy court; the swein-gcmotc, or forest court; the wardmote, or ward court, Wharton; Cunningham
The head of a family
In Saxon law. A villein, or agricultural tenant, (villans villicus;) a hind or farmer, (firmarius Rusticus.) Spelman
Lat. In the civil law. A son-in-law; a da ugh ter'8 husband. (filial VIR.) Dig. 38, 10, 4, 6

Pertaining to, or designating, the genus or class, as distinguished from that which characterizes the species or individual. Universal, not particularized; as opposed to special. Principal or central; as opposed to local, open or available to all, as opposed to select, obtaining commonly, or recognized universally; as opposed to particular. Universal or unbounded; as opposed to limited. Comprehending the whole, or directed to the whole; as distinguished from anything applying to or designed for a portion only
The usual commons ln a religious house, distinguished from pietan-tin, which on extraordinary occasions were allowed beyond the commons. Cowell
Chiefs of the several orders of monks, friars, and other religious societies
The issue or offspring of a mother-monastery. Cowell
May mean either a degree of removal in computing descents, or a single succession of living beings ln natural descent Mcmillan v. School Committee, 107 N. C. 609, 12 S. E. 330, 10 L. R. A. 823
Lat Gentleman; a gentleman. Spelman
A degree of consanguinity. Spelman
Lat. In Roman law. A tribe or clan; a group of families, connected by common descent and bearing the same name, being all freeborn and of free ancestors, and in possession of full civic rights
Lat People. Contra omnes gentes, against all people. Bract, fol. 37b. words used In the clause of warranty in old deeds
In Roman law. The members of a gens or common tribe
In English law. A person of superior birth
A woman of birth above the common, or equal to that of a gentleman; an addition of a woman's state or degree
See Hindu Law

As applied to notes, bonds, and other. written Instruments, this term means that they are truly what they purport to be, and that they are not false, forged, fictitious, simulated, spurious, or counterfeit. Baldwin v. Van Dusen, 37 N. Y. 492; Smelter v. white, 92 U. 8. 392, 23 L. Ed. 508; Dow v. Penny, 29 Mo. 390; Cox v. Northwestern Stage Co. , 1 Idaho, 379

In the civil law. A general class or division, comprising several species. In toto jure genera per species derogator, et illus potisaimum habeus quod ad species direct eat, throughout the law, the species takes from the genus, and that is most particularly regarded which refers to the species. Dig. 50, 17, 80
An English gold coin, value 6s. 8d
In old New York law. A court messenger or constable. o'cal-iaghan, New Neth. 322

In Saxon law. Greve, reve, or reeve; a ministerial officer of high antiquity in England; answering to the grave or graf (grafin) of the early continental nations. The term was applied to various grades of officers, from the seitre-gerefa, shirc-grefe, or shire-rere, who had charge of the county, (and whose title aud office have been perpetuated in the modern "sheriff, ") down to the tun-gerefa, or town-reeve, and lower. Burrill
Bearing. Grens datum, bear-lug date. l'ld. Rays. 336; Hob. 19
Lat. Descended of the same stock, or from the same couple of ancestors; of the whole or full blood. Mackled. Rom. Law, f 145
Lat. A sprout of the earth. A young tree, so called
In the civil law. officers appointed to manage hospitals for the aged poor
In the civil law. An institution or hospital for taking care of the old. Cod. 1, 3, 46, 1; Calvin

A name given to the process of dividing a state or other territory into the authorized civil or political divisions, but with such a geographical arrangement as to accomplish a sinister or unlawful purpose, as, for instance, to secure a majority for a given political party in districts where the result would be otherwise if they were divided according to obvious natural lines, or to arrange school districts so that children of certain religions or nationalities shall be brought within one district and those of a different religion or nationality in another district. State v. Whitford, 54 wis. 150, 11 N. W. 424
In old English law. Finable; liable to be amerced at the discretion of the lord of a manor. Cowell
In old English law. Expense; reward; compensation; wealth. It ls also used for a fine or compensation for an offense. 2 Mon. Angl. 973
In Saxon law. A guest A name given to a stranger on the second night of his entertainment ln another's house. Twa-Night gest
In medical jurisprudence. The time during which a female, who has conceived, carries the embryo or foetus in her uterus.
In the civil law. Behavior or conduct
In the civil law. one who acts for another, or transacts another's business. Calvin
An ancient and obsolete writ resorted to when a person's good behavior was impeached. Lamb. Eir. 1. 4, c. 14

Lat. In Roman law. A deed or act; a thing done. Some writers affected to make a distinction between "gcstum" and "factum: But the best authorities pronounced this subtile and indefensible. Dig. 50, 16, 58
In old Scotch law. Gaolers. 1 Pity. Crim. Tr. pt. 2, p. 234
In Saxon law. The ancient convention of the people to decide a cause
In Saxon and old Engiish law. The giving of evidence
In Saxon law. Deeds or charters; writings. 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 10

A gallows; the post on which malefactors are hanged, or on which their bodies are exposed. It differs from a common gallows, in that it consists of one perpendicular post, from the top of which proceeds one arm, except it be a double gibbet, which is formed in the shape of the Roman capital T. Enc. Loud

A voluntary conveyance of land, or transfer of goods, from one person to another. made gratuitously, and not upon any consideration of blood or money. 2 Bl. Comm. 440; 2 Steps. Comm. 102; 2 Kent, Comm. 437. And see Ingram v. Coggan, 106 Cal. 113, 38 Pac. 315, 28 L. R. A. 187, 40 Am. St. Rep. 221; Gray v. Barton, 55 N. Y. 72, 14 Am. Rep. 181; Williamson v. Johnson, 62 Vt. 378, 20 At. 279, 9 L. R. A. 277, 22 Am. St. Rep. 117; Flanders v. Brandy, 45 ohio St. 113, 12 N. E. 321
The stream of water to a mill. Mon. Angl. tom. 3
In Swedish law. The right to dispose of a woman in marriage; or the person possessing such right, her father, if living, or, if he be dead, the mother
In Saxon law. A tax or tribute. Spelman
A gild mer-ebant, or merchant gild; a gild, corporation, or company of merchants. 10 Coke, 30
In old English law. Taxiable, tributary, or contributory; liable to pay tax or tribute. Cowell; Blount
In Saxon law. Members of a gild or decennary, oftener spelled "con-gildo. " Du Change; Spelman
L. Fr. A cheat or deceiver. Applied ln Britton to those who sold false or spurious things for good, as pewter for silver or laten for gold. Britt c. 15
An Italian word, which signifies the drawer of a bill. It is derived from "giarre, " to draw
In Saxon aud old English law. A measure of length, equal to one yard, derived from the girth or circumference of a man's body
L. Fr. Agistment; cattle taken in to graze at a certain price; also the money received for grazing cattle
L. Fr. To lie. Gist en le bouche, it lies in the mouth. Le action bien gist, the action well lies. Gisant, lying
An agister; a person who takes cattle to graze
In Saxon law. A pledge. Fred-Gisle, a pledge of peace. Qislebert, an illustrious pledge
In pleading. The essential ground or object of the action in point of law, without which there would be no cause of action. Gould, Pl. c. 4, S 12; Hathaway v. Race, 19 Vt. 102

1. To transfer or yield to, or bestow upon, another, one of the operative words in deeds of conveyance of real property, importing at common law, a warranty or covenant for quiet enjoyment during the lifetime of the grantor. Mack v. Patching, 29 How. Pray. (N. Y.) 23; Young v. Margrave, 7 ohio, 69, pt 2; Dow v. Lewis, 4 Gray (mass.) 473
A donor; he who makes a gift

In Louisiana law. A phrase (translating the Fr. "ration en payment") which signifies the delivery and acceptance of real or personal property in satisfaction of a debt, Instead of a payment in money. See Civil Code La. art 2655
A ceremony anciently performed In England by serjeants at law at the time of their appointment. The rings were inscribed with a motto, generally ln Latin
A little sword or dagger; a kind of sedge. Mat. Paris
Lat. A sword. An ancient emblem of defense. Hence the ancient earls or comites (the king's attendants, advisers, and associates in his government) were made by being girt with swords, (gladi succinct
A sword, lance, or horseman's staff, one of the weapons allowed ln a trial by combat
In the call law. Acorns or nuts of the oak or other trees. In a larger sense, all fruits of trees
A term used In St. 1 Jac
A hand dart Cowell
The gathering of grain after reapers, or of grain left ungathered by reapers. Held not to be a right at common law. 1 H. Bl. 51
A turf, sod, or clod of earth. The soil or ground; cultivated land in general. Church land, (solum et dos ecclesia#.) Spelman. See Glebe
Villein-Socmen, who could not be removed from the land while they did the service due. Bract, c. 7; 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 269
Turfs dug out of the ground. Cowell
In ecclesiastical law. The
In Saxon law. A frater-ulty
Commissioners appointed to determine differences between scholars ln a school or university and the townsmen of the place. Jacob
Lat. In the civil law. A husband's sister. Dig. 38, 10, 4, 6

An interpretation, consisting of one or more words, interlinear or marginal; an annotation, explanation, or comment on any passage in the text of a work, for purposes of elucidation or amplification. Particularly applied to the comments on the Corpus Juris

Lat. A gloss, explanation, or interpretation. The gloss# of the Roman law are brief illustrative comments or annotations on the text of Justinian'S collections, made by the professors who taught or lectured on them about the twelfth century, (especially at the law school of Bologna,) and were hence called "glossators. " These glosses were at first inserted in the text with the words to which they referred, and were called "gloss# interlincarcsbut afterwards they were placed in the margin, partly at the aide, and partly under the text, and called "gloss# marginals" A selection of them was made by Accuraius, between A. D. 1220 and 1200. under the title of "flossa Ordin-Aria" which is of the greatest authority. Mackled. Rom. Law, 90
In the civil law. A commentator or annotator. A term applied to the professors and teachers of the Roman law in the twelfth century, at the head of whom was Irnerius. Mackled. Rom. Law, S 90

Extraordinary rewards formerly given to officers of courts, etc. ; money formerly given by the sheriff of a county in which no offenders are left for execution to the clerk of assize and judges' officers. Jacob

It was an ancient custom on a maiden assize, when there was no offender to be tried, for the sheriff to present the judge with a pair of white gloves. It is an immemorial custom to remove the glove from the right hand on taking oath, Wharton
YN. A hollow between two mountains; a valley or glen. Co. Litt. 5b

In old English law. A contrivance or structure for draining waters out of the land into the sea. Calls described goats as "usual engines erected and built with portcullises and doors of timber and stone or brick. Invented first ln Lower Germany. " Calls, Sewers, (91.) 112, 113. Cowbell defines "gote, " a ditch, fewer, or gutter
The an
An ecclesiastical or church fine paid for crimes and offenses committed against God. Cowell
That which is offered to God or his service. Jacob
An old form of the word "cucking-stool, " (q. v.) Cowell
In various compound phrases (as those which follow) this term implies either motion, progress, active operation, or present and continuous validity and efficacy
A mine. Blount A sank or passage for water. Cowell
A mulct or fine In gold
L. Lat. A jester, buffoon, or juggler. Spelman, voc. "goliar-densis
In Hindu law. An agent; a steward; a confidential factor; a representative
In medical jurisprudence. A venereal disease, characterized by a purulent inflammation of the urethra
1. Valid; sufficient in law; effectual; unobjectionable
The flctl-tious plaintiff in the old action of ejectment, most frequently called "john Doe, " was sometimes called "goodnight" or "goodtitle. "

In contracts. The term "goods" Is not so wide as "chattels, " for it applies to Inanimate objects, and does not include animals or chattels real, as a lease for years of house or land, which "chattels" does Include. Co. Litt. 118; St. Joseph Hydraulic Co. v. wilson, 133 Ind. 465, 33 N. E. 113
In did English law. A breach in a bank or sea wall, or a passage worn by the flux and reflux of the sea. St. 16 17 Car. II. c. 11
E, or GOES. A wear, pool, or pit of water. Termes de la Ley

In old English law, a small, narrow slip of ground. Cowell. In modem laud law, a small triangular piece of land, such as may be left between surveys which do not close. In some of the New England states (as, Maine and Vermont) the term is applied to a subdivision of a county, having a scanty population and for that reason not organized as a town
In canon law. Compa-Teruity; spiritual affinity

In medical jurisprudence. An inflammation of the fibrous and ligamentous parts of the joints, characterized or caused by an excess of uric acid in the blood; usually, but not invariably, occurring in the joints of the feet, and then specifically called "podagra. "
I. The regulation, restraint, supervision, or control which is ex
The title of the chief executive in each of the states and territories of the United States; and also of the chief

This word is commonly used in contradistinction to "right" Thus, in SL 22 Ed. III. , the lord chancellor was instructed to take cognizance of matters of grace, being such subjects of equity jurisdiction as were exclusively matters of equity. Brown
Time of indulgence granted to an acceptor or maker for the payment of his bill of exchange or note. It was originally a gratuitous favor, (hence the name,) but custom has rendered it a legal right
In old English law. By degrees or steps; step by step; from one degree to another. Bract fol. 64
In the civil and old English law. A measure of space. A degree of relationship
A pedigree; a table of relationship
In old English law. A graffer, notary, or scrivener. St. 5 Hen. VEIL c. 1
A notary or scrivener. See St 5 Hen. VEIL c. 1. The word is a corruption of the French "greffier" (q. v
A writing-book, register, or cartulary of deeds and evidences. Cowell
A baron, inferior to a count. A fiscal judge. An advocate. Spelman; Cowbell

A term used in equity to devote the confirmation, by relation back, of the right of a mortgagee in premises to which, at the making of the mortgage, the mortgagor had only an imperfect title, but to which the latter has since acquired a good title
In Troy weight, the twenty-fourth part of a pennyweight Any kind of corn sown in the ground
An ancient duty in London under which the twentieth part of salt imported by aliens was taken

In England, this term designates a school in which such instruction is given as will prepare the student to enter a college or university, and in this sense the phrase was used in the Massachusetts colonial act of 1647, requiring every town containing a hundred householders to set up a "grammar school. " See Jenkins v. Andover, 108 Mass. 97. But in modern American usage the term denotes a school, intermediate between the primary school and the high school, in which English grammar and other studies of that grade are taught
(gneco-lat.) In the civil law. A place for keeping writings or records. Dig. 48, 19, 9, 6

The unit of weight In the metric system. The gramme is the weight of a cubic centimeter of distilled water at the temperature of 4deg C. It is equal to 15. 4341 grains troy, or 5. 6481 drachms avoirdupois
In old English law. An officer having charge of a granary. Fleta, llb. 2, c. 82, { 1; Id. c. 84
As to grand "assize, " "bill of Sale, " "cape, " "distress, " "jury, " "larceny, " and "serjeanty, " see those titles
A collection of customs, laws, and forms of procedure ln use in early times ln France. See Couru-M1Eb

In English practice. Certain days in the terms, which are solemnly kept in the inns of court and chancery, viz. , Candlemas day lu Hilary term, Ascension day in Easter, St John the Baptist'S day in Trinity, and All Saints in Mlchael-Mas; which are dies non juridic. Termes de la Ley; Cowell; Blount They are days Bet apart for peculiar festivity; the members of the respective inns being on such occasions regaled at their dinner in the hall, with more than usual sumptuousness. Hothouse
The child of one's child
The father of either of one's parents
The mother of either of one's parents
A farm furnished with barns, granaries, stables, and all conveniences for husbandry. Co. Litt 5a
A keeper of a grange or farm
A grange. Co. Litt 5a
A generic term applicable to all transfers of real property. 3 wash. Real Prop. 181, 353
The person to whom a grant ls made
The person by whom a grant is made
In old English law. Noblemen or grandees. Jacob
In old records. The grazing or turning up the earth with a plow. The name of a customary service for inferior tenants to bring their plows, and do one day's work for their lords. Cowell
Rogation week, so called anciently ln the inns of court and chancery
A slang term for a woman separated from her husband by abandonment or prolonged absence; a woman living apart from her husband, webster
Or GRASSUM. A fine paid upon the transfer of a copyhold estate
A gratuity; a recompense or reward for services or benefits, given voluntarily, without solicitation or promise
Freely; gratuitously; without reward or consideration

A voluntary assertion; a statement which a party is not legally hound to make, or in which he is not held to precise accuracy. 2 Kent, Comm. 486, Mercury v. watson, 6 Met. (mass.) 260, 39 Am. Dec. 726
In old English law. A grove; a small wood; a coppice or thicket Co. Litt. 4b
The burden or gist of a charge; the grievance or injury specially complained
In old English law. An accusation or Impeachment Leg. Ethel, c. 19
A sepulcher. A place where a dead body is interred

A cemetery; a place for the interment of dead bodies; sometimes defined in statutes as a place where a minimum number of persons (as "six or more") are buried. See Stockton v. weber, 98 Cal. 433, 33 Pac. 832
Grievous; great Ad grave damnum, to the grievous damage. 11 Coke, 40

A graf; a chief magistrate or officer. A term derived from the more ancient "grafin: ' and used ln combination with various other words, os an official title in Germany; as Margravius, Rheingravius, Landgravius, etc. Spelman

As used in various compound legal terms, this word generally means extraordinary, that ls, exceeding the common or ordinary measure or standard, ln respect to physical size, or Importance, dignity, etc. See Gulf, etc. , R. Co. v. Smith, 87 Tex. 348, 28
Satisfaction for an offense committed or injury done. Cowell
A colloquial expression to signify a time indefinitely remote, there being no such division of time known to the Greeks

In English law. A board or court of justice held in the countinghouse of the king's (or queen's) household, and composed of the lord steward and inferior officers. It takes LTS name from the green cloth spread over the board at which it ls held, Wharton; Cowell
A feudal custom in the manor of written, ln Essex, where every tenant whose front door opens to Greenburg shall pay a halfpenny yearly to the lord, by the name of "green silver" or "rent" Cowbell
In English law. The name of the estreats in the exchequer, delivered to the sheriff under the seal of that court which was impressed upon green wax

The popular and almost exclusive name applied to all United States treasury Issues. It is not applied to any other species of paper currency; and, when employed in testimony by way of description, is as certain ns the phrase "treasury notes. " Hickey v. State, 23 Ind. 23. And see U. S. v. Howell (D. C.) G4 Fed. 114; Spencer v. Prlndle, 28 Cal. 276; Levy v. State, 79 Ala. 261
In forest law. The same as vert, (q. v.) Termes de la Ley

In French law. Registrars, or clerks of the courts. They are officials attached to the courts to assist the Judges in their duties. They keep the minutes, write out the judgments, orders, and other decisions given by the tribunals, and deliver copies thereof to applicants
The code or collection of constitutions made by the Roman jurist Gregorius. See Codex Gregorianus
The time from which the Gregorian calendar or computation dates; i. e. , from the year 1582
In Spanish law. A guild; an association of workmen, artificers, or merchants following the same trade or business; designed to protect and further the interests of their craft
Lat The bosom or breast; hence, derivatively, safeguard or protection. In English law, an estate which ls in abeyance ls said to be in gremio legis; that is, in the protection or keeping of the law
The statute 10 Geo. III. c. 16, by which the jurisdiction over par-11a men try election petitions was transferred from the whole house of commons to select committees Repealed by 9 Geo. IV. c. 22. ll
In English law. A customary fine due from a copyhold tenant on
In old records. The sea shore, sand, or each. 2 Mon. Angl. 625; Cowell
Aggrieved. 3 East, 22
In Saxon law. Peace; protection
An English silver coin (value four pence) Issued from the fourteenth to the seventeenth century. See Reg. v. Connell, 1 Car. K. 191
In old English law. A merchant or trader who engrossed all vendible merchandise; an engrosser. St. 37 Ed. III. c. 5. See Exgbosseb
A liquor saloon, barroom, or dramshop; a place where intoxicating liquor is sold to be drunk on the premises. See Leesburg v. Putnam, 103 Ga. 110, 29 S. E. 602
In old records. A deep hollow or pit; a bog or miry place. Cowell
In England. An officer of the royal household, who has charge of the king's w'ardrobe
Formerly an officer belonging to the royal household. Jacob
Great; culpable. General. Absolute or entire. A thing in gross exists in its own right, and not as an appendage to another thing
Fr. In French marine law. The contract of bottomry. Drd, Mar. ll. 3, txt 5
Timber. Cowell
L. Fr. Largely, greatly. (jrossemcnt ensaint, big with child. Plow. 76
In old English law. A fine, or sum of money paid for a lease. Plow. 270, 271. Supposed to be a corruption of gersum, (q. v.) See Gbessume
1. Soli; earth; a portion of the earth's surface appropriated to private use and under cultivation or susceptible of cultivation
A custom or tribute paid for the standing of shipping in port. Jacob
A crop must be considered and treated as a growing crop from the time the seed Is deposited in the ground, as at that time the seed loses the qualities of a chattel, and becomes a part of the free
A rate paid ln some places for the tithe of every fat beast, ox, or other unfruitful cattle. Clay 92

In mining law. A contract between two parties by which one undertakes to furnish the necessary provisions, tools, and other supplies, and the other to prospect for and locate mineral lands and stake out mining claims thereon, the interest ln the property thus acquired inuring to the benefit of both parties, either equally or in such proportions as their agreement may fix Such contracts create a qualified or special partnership. See Berry v. Woodburn, 107 Cal. 512, 40 Pac. 804; Hartley v. Gosling, 10 Wyo. 346, 68 Pac. 1118, 98 Am. St. Rep. 1005; Merlette V. Brennan, 20 Colo. 242, 88 Pac. 75
In old European law. A pledge. Spelman; Calvin. A custom. Spellman. Spelled also "wada

He to whom a guaranty is made. This word ls also used, as a noun, to denote the contract of guaranty or the obligation of a guarantor, and, as a verb, to denote the action of assuming the responsibilities of a guarantor. But on the general principle of legal orthography, that the title of the person to whom the action passes over should end in "ee, " as "donee, " "grantee, " "payee, " "bailee, " "drawee, " etc. , it seems better to use this word only as thecorrelative of "guarantor, " and to spell the verb, and also the name of the contract, "guaranty
In Spanish law. A written authorization to a court to enforce the performance of an agreement in the same manner as if it had been decreed upon regular legal proceedings
He who makes a guaranty
A state of wardship

A guardian is a person lawfully invested with the power, and charged with the duty, of taking care of the person and managing the property and rights of another person, who, for some peculiarly of status, or defect of age, understanding, or self-control, is considered incapable of administering his own affairs. Bass v. Cook, 4 Port. (ala.) 392; Sparhawk v. Allen, 21 N. H. 27; Burger v. Frakes, 67 Iowa, 460, 23 N. W, 746
The office, duty, or authority of a guardian. Also the relation subsisting between guardian and ward
A guardian, warden, or keeper. Spelman
In old European law. A provision of necessary things. Spellman. A furnishing or garnishment
One who had the custody of the royal mansions
L. Fr. Abandoned; left; deserted. Britt c. 33

In military law. An independent body of marauders or armed men, not regularly or organically connected with the armies'of either belligerent, who carry on a species of irregular war, chiefly by depredation and massacre
A traveler who lodges at an inn pr tavern with the consent of the keeper. Bac. Abr. "inns, " C, 5; 8 Coke, 32; Mcdaniels v. Robinson, 20 Vt. 316. 62 Am. Dec. 574; Johnson v. Reynolds, 3 Kan. 261
An agister; one who took cattle in to feed in the royal forests. Cowell
In old French law. watch, ord. Mar. Liv. 4, txt 6
In Spanish law. A right of way for narrow carts, white, New Rebop. L 2, c. 6, | 1
In old English law. That which was given for safe conduct through a strange territory, or another's territory. Cowell
An iron or steel plate to he attached to a rail for the purpose ot guiding to their place on the rail wheels thrown oft the track. Pub. St Mass. 1882, p. 1291
The name of a treatise on maritime law, by an unknown author, supposed to have been written about 1671 at Rouen, and considered, in continental Europe, as a work of high authority

A voluntary association of persons pursuing the same trade, art, profession, or business, such as printers, goldsmiths, wool merchants, etc. , united under a distinct organization of their own. analogous to that of a corporation, regulating the affairs of their trade or business by their own laws and rules, and aiming, by cooperation and organization, to protect and promote the interests of their common vocation. In medieval history these fraternities or guilds played an important part ln the government of some states; as at Florence, in the thirteenth and following centuries, where they chose the council of government of the city. But with the growth of cities and the advance in the organization of municipal government, their importance and prestige has declined. The place of meeting of a guild, or association of guilds, was called the "guildhall. " The word Is said to be derived from the Anglo-Saxon "gild" or "geld, " a tax or tribute, because each member of the society was required to pay a tax towards its support
The hall or place of meeting of a guild, or gild

An instrument for decapitation, used in France for the infliction of the death penalty on convicted criminals, consisting, essentially, of a heavy and weighted knife-blade moving perpendicularly between grooved posts, which ls made to fall from a considerable height upon the neck of the sufferer, immovably fixed ln position to receive the impact
In criminal law. That quality which imparts criminality to a motive or act, and renders the person amenable to punish, ment by the law

Having committed a crime or tort; the word used by a prisoner In pleading to an indictment when he confesses the crime of which he is charged, and by the jury in convicting. Com. v. waiter, 83 Pa. 108, 24 Am. Rep. 154; Jessie v. State, 28 Miss. 106; State V. white, 25 wis. 359

A coin formerly issued by the English mint, but all these coins were called in ln the time of wm. IV. The word now means only the sum of PS1. Is. , ln which denomination the fees of counsel are always given
The first of August, being the day of St. Peter ad Vincula

The heraldic name of the color usually called "red. " The word ls derived from the Arabic word "pule, " a rose, and was probably Introduced hy the Crusaders. Gales is denoted IU engravings by numerous perpendicular lines. Heralds who blazoned

Lat. Properly a whirlpool, but in old English law and conveyancing, a deep PLT filled with water, distinguished from "stagnum, " which was a shallow pool or pond. Co. Litt. 6; Johnson v. Rayner, 6 Gray (mass.) 107
Wears. Jacob
Jutes; one of the three nations who migrated from Germany to Britain at an early period. According to Spelman, they established themselves chiefly ln Kent and the Isle of wight

The dlmlnudve of a sewer. Calls, Sew. (80,) 100. In modern law, an open ditch or conduit designed to allow the passage of water from one point to another ln a certain direction, whether for purposes of drainage, lrrlgatlon, or otherwise, warren v. Henry, 31 Iowa, 31; Willis v. State, 27 Neb. 98, 42 N. W. 920
Maid'S fee. A British word signifying a customary fine payable to lords of some manors on marriage of the tenant's daughters, or otherwise on their committing incontinence. Cowell
A place of execution. Jacob
Half, or walked; that which has been stolen and afterwards dropped ln the highway for fear of a discovery. Cowell
The name of a court which was held every three weeks ln the liberty or hundred of Pathbew ln Warwick. Jacob
Sax. Compensation for fraud or trespass. Cowell
R GYNSGOORAGY. Government by a woman; a state in which women are legally capable of the supreme command; e. g. , ln Great Brutal and Spain
Wandering monks
Fetters or shackles for the legs
Or HAVE. Lat A form of the salutatory expression "ave, " (hail,) ln the titles of the constitutions of the Theodosian and Justinianean Codes. Calvin; Spelman

A writ commanding the sheriff to bring up the persons of jurors, and, if need were, to distrain them of their lands and goods, in order to Insure or compel their attendance ln court on the day of trial of a cause. It issued from the Common Pleas, and served the same purpose as a distringas juratores ln the Klng'S Bench. It was abolished by the C. L. P. Act, 1852, | 104. Brown.

Lat. (you have the body.) The name given to a variety of writs, (of which these were anciently the emphatic words,) having for their object to bring a party before a court or Judge. In common usage, aud whenever these words are used alone, they are understood to mean the habeas corpus ad subjiciendum, (see infra

Lat. In conveyancing. Time clause usually following the granting part of the premises of a deed, which defines the extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the grantee. 3 wash. Real Prop. 437; New York Indians v. U. S. , 170 U. S. 1, 18 Sup. Ct. 531, 42 L. Ed. 927; Clapp v. Byrnes, 3 App. Dlg. 284, 38 N. V. Supp. 1063; Milder v. Graham
In old English law. Rich men; literally, having men. The same with fees ting-men, (q. v.) Cowell
Riches, Mon. Angl. t 1, 100
Lat. In the kivu law. To have. Sometimes distinguished from tenure, (to held,) and possidere, (to possess;) habere referring to the right, tenure to the fact, and possidere to both. Calvin

Lat. That you cause to have possession. The name of the process commonly resorted to by the successful party in an action of ejectment, for the purpose of being placed by the sheriff ln the actual possession of the land recovered. It is commonly termed simply "habere facias: or "hab. fa.
Lat. That you cause to have a view. A writ to cause the sheriff to take a view of lands or tenements

Lat. In Roman law. To allow [one] to have [possession. ] This phrase denoted the duty of the seller of property to allow the purchaser to have the possession and enjoyment. For a breach of this duty, an action ex empty might be maintained
A cloth of a mixed color. Magna Charta, c. 26
Lat. Have or take your effects to yourself, one of the old Roman forms of divorcing a wife. Cal vin
Lat. Fit; suitable; active; useful, (of a servant.) Proved; authentic, (of Book of Saints.) Fixed; stable, (of authority of the king.) Du Change

A disposition or condition of the body or mind acquired by custom or a usual repetition of the same act or function. Knickerbocker L. Ins. Co. v. Foley, 105 U. S. 354, 26 L. Ed. 1055; Conner v. Citizens' St. R. Co. , 146 Ind. 430, 45 N. E. 662; State v. Skil

A covenant by a lessee to "pat the premises into habitable repair" binds bim to pat them into such a state that they may he occupied, not only with safety, but with reasonable comfort, for the purposes for which they are taken. Miller v. Mccardell, 19 R. I. 304, 33 Ati. 445, 30 L. R. A. 682

Settled dwelling ln a given place; fixed and permanent residence there. This term is more comprehensive than "domicile, " for one may he domiciled ln a given place though he does not spend the greater portion of his time there, or though he may be absent for long periods. It is also more comprehensive than "residence, " for one may reside in a given place only temporarily or for short periods on the occasion of repeated visits. But in neither case could he properly be called an "inhabitant" of that place or be said to have his "habitancy" there. See Atkinson v. washington Jefferson College, 54 W. Va. 32, 46 S. B. 253; Hairstone v. Hairstone, 27 Miss. 711, 61 Am. Dec. 530; Abington v. North Bridgewater, 23 Pick. (mass.) 170. And see Domicile; Residence
Fr. In French and Canadian law. A resident tenant; a settler; a tenant who kept hearth and home on the seigniory
Lat In the kivu law. The right of dwelling; the right of free residence in another's house. Inst. 2, 5; Dig. 7, 8
In the civil law. The

By statute in several states, one who ls convicted of a felony, having been previously convicted of any crime (or twice so convicted) , or who is convicted of a misdemeanor and has previously (in New York) been five times convicted of a misdemeanor. Crim. Code N. Y. 1903, SS 510; Rev. SL Utah, 1898, g 4067. In a more general sense, one made subject to police surveillance and arrest on suspicion, on account of his previous criminal record and absence of honest employment

A person given to ebriety or the excessive use of intoxicating drink, who has lost the power or the will, by frequent indulgence, to control his appetite for it Ludwick v. Com. , 18 Pa. 174; Gournay v. Gournay, 16 R. I. 705, 19 At. 142; Miskey'S Appeal, 107 Pa. 626; Richards v. Richards, 19 UL App. 467; Mcbee v. Mcbee, 22 Or. 329, 29 Pac. 887, 29 Am. St. Rep. 613
L. Fr. In old English law. A port or harbor; a station for ships. St. 27 Hen. VI. c. 3

Iu Spanish law. The public domain; the royal estate; the aggregate wealth of the state. The science of administering the national wealth; public economy. Also an estate or farm belonging to a private person
Carriages plying for hire In the street. The driver is liable for negligently losing baggage. Masterson v. Short, 33 How. Pray. (N. Y.) 486
In Saxon law. A recompense or satisfaction for the violation of holy orders, or violence offered to persons in holy orders. Cowell; Blount
In old English law. Hatred; ill will; prejudice, or partiality. Spelman; Cowell
In old English law. A tax or mulct. Jacob
Lat This ls an agreement, words with which agreements anciently commenced. Years. H. 6 Ed. II. 191
In Gothic law. A tribunal answering to the English court-leet
An ancient writ that lay for the lord, who, having by right the wardship of bis tenant under age, could not obtain his person, the same being carried
An ancient writ that lay for the ravishment of the lord's ward. Reg. org. 163
Lat In the call law. Heirs. The plural of teres, (q. v
Lat. In old English law. A seeker of an Inheritance; hence, the next heir to lands
In Roman law. The

In Roman law. The heir, or universal successor ln the event of death. The her is he who actively or passively succeeds to the entire property of the estate-leaver. He ls not only the successor to the rights and claims, but also to the estate-leav-er's debts, and in relation to his estate is to be regarded as the Identical person of the estate-leaver, inasmuch as he represents him ln all his active and passive relations to his estate. Mackled. Rom. Law, 651
A haven or port Cowell
A house in a city or borough. Scott
A hedge. Mon. Angl. tom. 2, p. 273
A little hand gun. SL 33 Hen. VIII. c. 6
A handgun of a larger description than the pagne. St 2 3 Ed
In old English law. A park inclosed. Cowell
In old English law. A permission or liberty to take thorns, etc. , to make or repair hedges. Blount
In Scotch law. whole; the whole. "all and hall" are common words ln conveyances. 1 Bell, App. Cas. 499
In Scotch law. The crime of assaulting a person in his own house. Belt

A moiety; one of two equal parts of anything susceptible of division. Prentiss v. Brewer, 17 wis. 644, 86 Am. Dec. 730; Hartford Iron Min. Co. v. Cambridge Min. Co. , 80 Mich. 491, 45 N. W. 351; Cogan v. Cook, 22 Minn. 142; Dart v. Barbour, 32 Much. 272. Used in law in various compound terms, in substantially the same sense, as follows

A synonym for lynch law, or the summary (and unauthorized) trial of a person accused of crime and the lnfllc-tlon of death upon him; from the name of the parish of Halifax, ln England, where ardently this form of private Justice was practised by the free burghers ln the case of persons accused of stealing; also called "gibbet law. "

In Saxon law. The meeting of a ball, (convents dulce,) that is, a lord's court; a court of a manor, or court-baron. Spelman. So called from the hall, where the tenants or freemen met, and justice was administered. Crabb, Eng. Law, 26
In English law. The feast of All Saints, on the 1st of November; one of the cross-quarters of the year, was computed from Halloas to Candlemas, Wharton
A bulldog or room of considerable size, used as a place for the meeting of public assemblies, conventions, courts, etc
In old English law. A fee or toll due for goods or merchandise vended in a hall. Jacob
In Spanish law. The'Flnd-Ing and taking possession of something which previously had no owner, and which thus becomes the property of the first occupant. Las Partitas, 3, 5, 28; 5, 48, 49; 5, 20, 50
In Saxon law. Hali-Gemot, (q. v

In medical jurisprudence. A trick or deceit of the senses; a morbid error either of the sense of sight or that of hearing, or possibly of the other senses; a psychological state, such as would be produced naturally by an act of sense-per-ceptlon, attributed confidently, but mistakenly, to something which has no objective existence; as, when the patient imagines that he sees an object when there ls none, or hears a voice or other sound when nothing strikes his ear. See Staples v. wellington, 58 Me. 459; Foster v. Dickerson, 64 VL 233, 24 At. 257; Mcnutt v. Cooper (C. C.) 13 Fed. 590; People v. Wrist, 168 N. Y. 19, 60 N. E. 1057
See Haligemot
A holy or ecclesiastical court
Sax, In old English law. Tenants who held land by the service of repairing or defending a church or monument, whereby they were exempted from feudal and military services
In old English law. A hook; an engine with which a house on fire is pulled down. Yet. 60
In forest law. The hoxing or hock-sinewing of dogs; an old mode of laming or disabling dogs. Termes de la Ley
In Scotch law. The violent entering into a man's house without license or against the peace, and the seeking and assaulting him there. Skene de Verb. Sign. ; 2 Forb. Inst. 139
(sax. From ham, a house.) In Saxon law. An assault made in a house; a breach of the peace in a private house
A small village; a part or member of a vill. It Is the dlmlnudve of "/tarn, " a village. Cowell. See Rex. v. Morris, 4 Term, 552
A close joining to a house; a croft; a little meadow. Cowell
Metaphorically, a forced sale or sale at public auction. "to bring to the hammer, " to put up for sale at auction. "sold under the hammer, " sold by an officer of the law or by an auctioneer
In Saxon law. The right of security and privacy in a man's house. Du Change. The breach of this privilege by a forcible entry of a house is breach of the peace. Du Change

A hamper or basket in which were kept the writs of the court of chaucer relating to the business of a subject, and their returns. 8 Bl. Comm. 49. According to others, the fees accruing on writs, etc. , were there kept. Spelman; Du Change
A measure of length equal to four inches, used in measuring the height ot horses. A person's signature
An appellate court ls sold to "haud down" Its decision in a. case, when the opinion ls prepared and filed for transmission to the court below
In old English law. Betrothment
In old English law. Peace or protection given by the king with his own hand
Money paid ln hand to bind a bargain; earnest money
A written or printed notice displayed to inform those concerned of something to be done. People v. Mclaughlin, 33 Misc. Rep. 691, 68 N. Y. Supp. 1106

In Saxon law. A hand pledge; a name given to the none pledges in a decennary or friborg; the tenth or chief, being called "headborow" (q. v.) So called as being an inferior pledge to the chief. Spelman
In Saxon law. one having a thing ln his hand; that is, a thief found having the stolen goods in his posses sion. Jurisdiction to try such thief

Anciently, among all the northern nations, shaking of hands was held necessary to band a bargain, a custom still retained in verbal contracts. A sale thus made was' called "handsale, " (vendition per mutual manus complexion.) In pro cess of time the same word was used to slg-nlfy the price or earnest which was given immediately after the shaking of hands, or instead thereof. 2 Bl. Comm. 448
Handsale, or earnest money

The chirography of a person; the cast or form of writing peculiar to a person, including the size, shape, and style of letters, tracks of penmanship, and whatever gives lndlvlduality to his writing, distinguishing it from that of other persons. In re Hyland'S will (sure. Ct.) 27 N. Y. Supp. 963
In old practice. To remain undetermined. 'tt has hung long enough; it is time it were made an end of. " Holt, C. J. 1 Show. 77
In criminal law. Suspension by the neck; the mode of capital punishment used in England from time immemorial, and generally adopted ln the United States. 4 Bl. Comm. 403
An executioner. One who executes condemned criminals by hanging
In Saxon law. A fine for Illegal hanging of a thief, or for allowing him to escape. Immunity from such fine. Du Conge
An alliance or confederation among merchants or cities, for the good ordering and protection of the commerce of its members. An Imposition upon merchandise. Du Change
The chief of a company; the head man of a corporation
In old European law. An arrest or attachment. Spelman

SS. The constitutional right of men to pursue their "happiness" means the right to pursue any lawful business or vocation, in any manner not inconsistent with the equal rights of others, which may Increase their prosperity, or develop their faculties, so as to give to them their highest enjoyment. Butchers' Union Co. v. Crescent City Co. , Ill U. S. 757, 4 Sup. CL 652, 28 L. Ed. 585; 1 Bl. Comm. 41. And see English v: English, 32 N. J. Eq. 750
In old statutes. A handgun, about three-quarters of a yard long
In old English law. A race of horses and mares kept for breed; a stud. Spelman
In England, an officer of the royal household

A punishment, additional to mere imprisonment, sometimes imposed upon convicts sentenced to a penitentiary. But the labor is not, as a rule, any harder than ordinary mechanical labor. Brown v. State, 74 Ala. 483
Lawful coined money. Henry v. Bank of Salina, 5 HUI (N. Y.) 523, ' 536
In old Scotch law. Lions; coins formerly of the value of three halfpence. 1 Pity. Crim. Tr. pt. 1, p. 64, note

The severity with which a proposed construction of the law would bear upon a particular case, founding, sometimes, au argument against such construction, which ls otherwise termed the "argument ab inconvenienti
See Elbow
In old European law. The defensive armor of a man; harness. Spelman
All warlike instruments; also the tackle or furniture of a ship
Fr. In Norman and early English law. An outcry, or hue and cry after felons and malefactors. Cowell
The old form of "heriot, " (q. v.) williams, Seis. 203
A stag or male deer of the forest five years old complete

In old Scotch law. Lie form of entering an her ln a subject situated within a royal borough. It consisted of the heir's taking hold of the hasp and staple of the door, (which was the symbol of possession,) with other formalities. Bell; Burrill
In old English law. The hasp of a door; by which livery of eelskin might anciently he made, where there was a house on the premises
In maritime law. Plumage; a small duty pale to the captain and mariners of a ship
O. Fr. A high lord; a great baron. Spelman
Or HOUGH. A green plot in a valley

The use of this word, instead of the statutory word "carry, " in an indictment charging that the defendant "did feloniously steal, take, and haul away" certain personalty, will not render the indictment bad, the words being in one sense equivalent. Spittorff v. State, 108 Ind. 171, 8 N. E. 911
In old English law. Hatred. Leg. wm. I. c. 16; Blount

Lat. In the call law. A species of servitude, consisting In the right to draw water from another's well or spring, in which the iter, (right of way to the well or spring,) so for as it ls necessary, is tacitly included. Dlg. 8, 3, 1; Mackled. Rom. Law, S 318
L. Fr. Highway. Years. M. 4 Hen. VI. 4
L. Fr. High street; highway. Years. P. 11 Hen. VI. 2
In old English law. A man armed with a coat of main. Jacob

To possess corporally. "no one, at common law, was said to have or to be in possession of land, unless it were conveyed to him by the livery of seisin, which gave him the corporal investiture and bodily occupation thereof. " Bl. Law Tracts, 113

A place of a large receipt and safe riding of ships, so situate and secured by the land circumjacent that the vessels thereby rode and anchor safely, and are protected hy the adjacent land from dangerous or violent winds; as Milford Haven, Plymouth Haven, and the like. Hale de Jure Mar. par. 2, c. 2. And see Lowndes v. Board of Trustees, 153 U. S. 1, 14 Sup. Ct. 758, 38 L. Ed. 615; De Longuemere v. New York Ins. Co. , 10 Johns. (N. Y.) 125(a) ; De Lovie v. Bolt, 7 Fed. Cas. 429

A coat or shirt of mail; hence, derivatively (in feudal law) one who held a fief on the duty or service of providing himself with such armor and standing ready, thus equipped, for military service when called on. Wharton
In old English law. A valley. Co. Litt. 5b
A trader who goes from place to place, or along the streets of a town, selling the goods which he carries with him

Another name for "hedgebote, " being one of the estovers allowed to a tenant for life or years, namely, material for repairing the necessary hedges or fences of his grounds. 2 Bl. Comm. 35; 1 wash. Real Prop. 129
In old English law. An officer appointed in the lord's court to keep
In old English law. An
Exposed to or involving danger; perilous; risky
Chief; leading; principal; the upper part or principal source of a stream
In Saxon law. The head or chief officer of a borough; chief of the frankpledge tithing or decennary. This office was afterwards, when the petty constableship was created, united with that office
Certain tribunals in Scotland, abolished by 20 Geo. II. c. 50. Esk. 1, 4, 5
In old English law. A narrow piece of unplowed land left at the end of a plowed field for the turning of the plow. Called, also, "butt"
A syllabus to a reported case; a summary of the points decided in the case, which is placed at the head or beginning of the report
An exaction of 40d. ob more, collected by the sheriff of Northumberland from the people of that county twice IU every seven years, without account to the king. Abolished in 1444. Cowell
In old English law. one of the services to be rendered by a thane, but in what it consisted seems uncertain
In Saxon law. A court-baron; an ecclesiastical court
In Saxon law. A sort of pillory, by which the head of the culprit was caught between two boards, as feet are caught ln a pair of stocks. Cowell
Another name for a curative act or statute. See Lockhart v. Troy, 48 Ala. 584

Freedom from sickness or suffering. The right to the enjoyment of health Is a subdivision of the right of personal security, one of the absolute rights of persons. 1 Bl. Comm. 129, 134. As to injuries affecting health, see 3 Bl. Comm. 122
Free from disease or bodily ailment, or any state of the system peculiarly susceptible or liable to disease or bod, ill ailment Bell v. Jeffreys, 35 N. C. 356. w
In equity practice. The

A term applied to that species of testimony given by a witness who relates, not what he knows personally, but what others have told him, or what he has heard said by others. Hope v. Utah, 110 U. S. 574, 4 Sup. Ct 202. 28 L. Ed. 262; Morell v. Morell, 157 Ind. 179, CO N. E. 1092; Stockton v. williams, 1 Doug. (mich.) 570; People v. Kraft, 91 Hun, 474, 36 N. Y. Supp. 1034
A tax levied In England by St. 14 Car. II. c. 10. consisting of two shillings on every hearth or stove in the kingdom. It was extremely unpopular, and was abolished by 1 W. M. St. 1, c
In English law. A species of modus or composition for tithes. Instr. 323. 326
In criminal law. A state of violent and uncontrollable rage

In maritime parlance and admiralty law. To stop a sailing vessel's headway by bringing her head "into the wind, " that is, in the direction from which the wind blows. A steamer is said to be "hove to" when held In such a position that she takes the heaviest seas upon her quarter. The Hugo (D. C.) 57 Fed. 411
An unlawful fisher in the Thames below London bridge; so called because they generally fished at ebbing tide or water. 4 Hen. VII. c. 15; Jacob
In Saxon law. The privilege of having the goods of a thief, and the trial of him, within a certain liberty. Cowell
A device for catching fish in ebbing water. St. 23 Hen. VIII. c. 5
A week's man; the canon or prebendary in a cathedral church, who had the peculiar care of the choir and the offices of it for his own week. Cowell
In feudal law. Rent

A small haven, wharf, or landing place

Smith, 96 Md. 393, 54 At. 102; Fletcher v. Holmes, 32 Ind. 510; Rewall v. Roberts, 115 Mass. 268; Dodge'S Appeal, 106 Pa. 216, 51 Am. Rep. 519; Howell v. Gifford, 64 N. J. Eq. 180, 53 At. 1074

Such goods and chattels as, contrary to the nature of chattels, shall go hy special custom to the heir along with the inheritance, and not to the executor. The termination "loom" (sax.) sig-niflee a limb or member; so that an heirloom ls nothing else but a limb or member of the inheritance. They are generally such things as cannot be taken away without damaging or dismembering the freehold; such as deer ln a park, doves ln a cote, deeds and charters, etc. 2 Bl. Comm. 427
Succession by inheritance
SS. A female heir to a person having an estate of inheritance. when there are more than one, they are called "co-heir-esses, " or "coheirs. "
A word used in deeds of conveyance, (either solely, or in connection with others,) where it ls intended to pass a fee
The quality or condition of being heir, or the relation between the heir and his ancestor

In Scotch law. The movables which go to the heir, and not to the executor, that the land may not go to the heir completely dismantled, such as the best of furniture, horses, cows, etc. , but not funglhles. Bell
The name formerly given to a place under the exchequer chamber, where the king's debtors were confined. Rich. Dict
Thatch or straw; a covering for the head in war; a coat of arms bearing a crest; the tiller or handle of the rudder of a ship
The end-wall covering and defending the rest of the building. Paroch. Antiq. 573
A Saxon brass coin, of the value of a halfpenny

In medical Jurisprudence. Unilateral paralysis; paralysis of one side of the body, commonly due to a lesion ln the brain, but sometimes originating from the spinal cord, as ln "brown-sequard's paralysis, " unilateral paralysis with crossed anaesthesia. In the cerebral form, the Hemiplegia is sometimes "alternate" or crossed, that ls, occurring on the opposite side of the body from the initial lesion
Or HELMELBORCH

A word of futurity, which, as employed ln legal documents, statutes, and the like, always imports a continuity of action or condition from the present time forward, hut excludes all the past Thomson v. American Surety Co. , 170 N. Y. 109, 62 N. E. 1073; opinion of Chief Justice, 7 Pick. (mass.) 128, note
A page; an attendant; a herald. See Barnes v. State, 88 Md. 347, 41 At. 781
A customary payment of money Instead of hens at Christmas; a composition for eggs. Cowell
A fine for flight on account of murder. Domesday Book
In Saxon law. A prison, a gaol, or house of correction
Sax. In old English law. An acquittance from a fine for hanging a thief. Fleta, llb. 1, c. 47, | 17
Henry the old, order. King Henry I. ls so called in ancient English chronicles and charters, to distinguish him from the subsequent kings of that name. Spelman
Peter-Pence, (q.
In Saxon law. The service of herdsmen, done at the will of their lord

A government exercised by seven persons, or a nation divided into seven governments. In the year 560, seven different monarchies had been formed ln England by the German tribes, namely, that of Kent by the Jutes; those of Sussex, Wessex, and Essex by the Saxons; and those of East Anglia, Bernicia, and Deina by the Angles. To these were added, about the year 586, an eighth, called the "kingdom of Mer-Cla, " also founded hy the Angles, and com-prehendlng nearly the whole of the heart of the kingdom. These states formed what has been designated the "anglo-saxon octarchy, " or more commonly, though not so correctly, the "anglo-saxon Heptarchy, " from the custom of speaking of Delia and Bernicia under the single appellation of the "kingdom of Northumberland. " Wharton

In ancient law, a herald was a diplomatic messenger tho carried messages between kings or states, and especially proclamations of war, peace, or truce. In English law, a herald is an officer whose duty is to keep genealogical lists and tables, adjust armorial bearings, and regulate the ceremonies at royal coronations and funerals
The art, office, or science of heralds. Also an old and obsolete abuse of buying and selling precedence in the paper of causes for hearing
In English law. An easement or liberty, which consists in the right to pasture cattle on another's ground
The first crop of grass or hay, in opposition to aftermath or second cutting. Paroch. Antiq. 459

Lodgings to receive guests ln the way of hospitality. Cowen
Harbored or entertained in an inn. Cowell

To harrow. 4 Inst. 270

In the call law. To be divided. Familia hcrcixcundo, an inheritance to be divided. Action family# herds-fund#, an action for dividing an inheritance. Erciscunda is more commonly used in the civil law. Dig. 10, 2; Inst 3, 28, 4; Id. 4, 6, 20
A grange or place for cattle or husbandry. Mon. Angl. pt 3
Herdsmen'S work, or customary labor, done by shepherds and inferior tenants, at the will of the lord. Cowell

The royal edict summoning the people to the field. Cowell

In Sicilian and Neapolitan law. That which ls held by hereditary right; the same with hercditamentum (hereditament) in English law. Spelman

Things capable of being inherited, he it corporeal or incorporeal. real, personal, or mixed, and including not only lands and everything thereon, but also heirlooms, and certain furniture which, by custom, may descend to the heir together with the land. A general, leader, or commander; also a baron of the realm. Dn Fresne

This term, as used In various compound legal phrases, is sometimes merely an addition of dignity, not Importing a comparison; hut more generally it means exalted, either in rank or location, or occupying a position of superiority, and ln a few instances it Implies superiority in respect to Importance, size, or frequency or publicity of use, e. g. , "high seas, " "highway. "

A title of honor given to princes. The kings of England, before the time of James I. , were not usually saluted with the title of "majesty, " but with that of "highness. " The children of crowned heads generally receive the style of "highness. " Wharton

A free and public road, way, or street; one which every person has the right to use. Abbott v. Duluth (C. C.) 104 Fed. 837; Shelby County Com'Rs v. Cas-Tetter, 7 Ind. App. 309, 83 N. B. 986; State v. A collection of orders and forms extensively modifying the pleading and practice in the English superior courts of common law, established in Hilary term, 1834. Stimson

In English law. A term of court, beginning on the 11th and ending on the 31st of January in each year. Superseded (1875) by Hilary sittings, which begin January 11th, and end on the wednesday before Easter

A society of men. The Saxons ranked men Into three classes, and valued them, as to. satisfaction for ln-jurles, etc. , according to their class. The highest class were valued at 1, 200s. , and were called "thelf Hindman; " the middle class at 600s. , and called "ttexhindmen the lowest at 200s. , called "ttryhindmen" Their wives were termed "hindus. " Prompt Leg. Alfred, c. 12

To hinder and delay is to do something which is an attempt to defraud, rather than a successful fraud; to put some obstacle in the path, or interpose some time, unjustifiably, before the creditor can realize what is owed out of his debtor's property. In Spanish law. A mortgage of real property

One who hares a thing, or the labor or services of another person. Turner v. Cross, 83 Tex. 218, 18 S. W. 578, 15 L. R. A. 262

The holder of a bill of exchange, promissory note, or check ls the person who bas legally acquired the possession of the same, from a person capable of transferring it, by indorsement or delivery, and who is entitled to receive payment of the instrument from the party or parties liable to meet it. In Spanish law. A holograph. An Instrument (particularly a will) wholly ln the handwriting of the person executing it; or which, to be valid, must be so written by his own hand

A service (or the ceremony of rendering it) which a tenant was bound to perform to his lord on receiving investiture of a fee, or succeeding to it as heir, in acknowledgment of the tenure. The ceremony was as follows: The tenant, being ungirt and with hare head, knelt before the lord

In Spanish law. The tacit consent and approval inferred by law from the omission of the parties, for the space of ten days, to complain of the sentences of arbitrators, appointment of syndics, or assignees of insolvents, settlements of successions, etc. Also the approval given by the judge of certain acts and agreements for the purpose of rendering them more binding and executory. Escrlche
In the civil law. To confirm or approve; to consent or assent; to confess. Calvin

In modern civil law. To approve; to confirm; as a court homologates a proceeding. See Homologation. Literally, to use the same words with another; to say the like. Vialed v. Gardener, 9 Mart. O. S. (la.) 324. To assent to what another says or writes

Lat. of good character or standing. Coram doubts vel pluribus virus legalibus ct honesties, before two or more lawful and good men. Bract fol. 6L
A title of courtesy given ln England to the younger children

As applied to public offices and other positions of responsibility or trust, this term means either that the office or title is bestowed upon the Incumbent as a mark of honor or compliment, without Intending to charge him with the active discharge of the duties of the place, or else that he ls to repel Ve no salary or other compensation ln money, the honor conferred by the Incumbency of the office being his only reward. In other connections, it means attached to or grew-lng out of some honor or dignity or honorable office, or else it imports an obligation or duty growing out of honor or trust only, ss distinguished from legal accountability
By reason of honor or privilege. See Challenge

L. Fr. Shame; evil; disgrace. Bony soft qui mal y pense, evil be to him who evil thinks
